Penyerahan baju Yusuf kepada ayahnya oleh Yahuda sebagai bukti bahwa Yusuf masih hidup mengingatkan Yakub pada penyerahan baju Yusuf yang berlumuran darah oleh Yahuda sebagai bukti bahwa Yusuf telah diterkam serigala.
text.97: Setelah saudara-saudara Yusuf melihat bukti-bukti dan kenyataan yang tidak dapat dipungkiri, mereka menjadi sadar dan dengan jujur mengakui kesalahannya. Mereka juga meminta kepada ayahnya agar mau memohonkan ampun kepada Allah swt atas kedurhakaan yang telah mereka perbuat kepada ayahnya dan kezaliman yang dilakukan terhadap Yusuf. Pengakuan saudara-saudara Yusuf tentang kesalahan dan dosa yang telah diperbuat itu adalah pengakuan yang kedua kalinya. Sebelum itu, mereka pernah mengakui dosa dan kesalahannya di hadapan Yusuf, hanya pada waktu itu Yusuf langsung memohonkan ampunan dari Allah swt tanpa permintaan dari mereka.
text.98: Setelah Yakub melihat kesadaran dan pengakuan anak-anaknya atas kesalahan yang mereka perbuat dengan terus terang serta permintaan mereka supaya ayahnya memohonkan ampunan kepada Allah swt, beliau menjawab, "Aku akan memohonkan ampun bagimu kepada Allah swt. Semoga Allah swt mengampunimu semua karena Dia Maha Pengampun dan Maha Penyayang. Allah tidak akan mengecewakan seorang mukmin yang memohon kepada-Nya dengan sungguh-sungguh."
text.99:
Pada ayat ini, dijelaskan bahwa saudara-saudara Yusuf pulang ke negerinya untuk memboyong semua keluarganya ke Mesir sesuai dengan anjuran Yusuf. Setelah sampai, mereka memberitahukan kepada kedua orang tuanya tentang kedudukan Yusuf di Mesir, dimana dia adalah penguasa yang berkuasa penuh di sana. Disampaikan pula bahwa Yusuf mengundang semua keluarganya untuk menetap di Mesir bersama-sama dengannya, menikmati kemajuan dan keindahan kota Mesir. Mendengar berita itu, berangkatlah mereka bersama-sama ke Mesir. Setelah sampai di Mesir mereka bertemu dengan Yusuf dan rombongan yang pergi menjemput mereka di tengah jalan. Yusuf merangkul kedua orang tuanya dan berkata, "Silakan memasuki negeri Mesir dengan selamat dan aman, insya Allah kamu sekalian tidak akan mengalami kesulitan dan kelaparan, sekalipun musim kemarau masih saja mencekam." Ucapan "Insya Allah" yang dikatakan Yusuf ini menjadi pelajaran bagi kita kaum Muslimin bahwa apabila hendak melakukan sesuatu, supaya disandarkan kepada kehendak Allah. Hal ini telah menjadi kebiasaan bagi para nabi dan shiddiqin. Hal tersebut sesuai pula dengan maksud firman Allah swt:

Dan jangan sekali-kali engkau mengatakan terhadap sesuatu, "Aku pasti melakukan itu besok pagi," kecuali (dengan mengatakan), "Insya Allah." (al-Kahf/18: 23 dan 24)
text.100:
Ayat ini menjelaskan Yusuf kemudian mengangkat kedua orang tuanya dan mendudukkan mereka di atas singgasana sebagai penghormatan lebih daripada apa yang telah diperbuat kepada saudara-saudaranya. Mereka merebahkan diri seraya sujud memberi hormat kepada Yusuf, sebagaimana lazimnya orang-orang memberi hormat kepada raja dan para pembesar pada waktu itu. Yusuf lalu berkata, "Wahai ayahku! Inilah takbir mimpiku dahulu ketika saya masih kecil yang telah saya sampaikan kepada ayah dengan ucapan:

Sungguh, aku (bermimpi) melihat sebelas bintang, matahari dan bulan; kulihat semuanya sujud kepadaku. (Yusuf/12: 4)

Lebih lanjut Yusuf berkata, "Allah swt menjadikan mimpiku itu benar-benar terjadi, bukan khayalan. Sebelas bintang itu adalah saudara-saudaraku yang berjumlah sebelas orang, sedang matahari dan bulan adalah ayah dan ibuku." Dengan keluarga inilah Allah swt memelihara keturunan Nabi Ishak, anak Nabi Ibrahim as, untuk mengembangkan agama tauhid di muka bumi ini. Selanjutnya Yusuf berkata kepada ayahnya, "Allah swt telah berbuat baik kepadaku. Dia melepaskan aku dari penjara dan mengangkatku sebagai penguasa. Dia memindahkan ayah dari dusun padang pasir berpenghidupan sederhana dan kasar, ke negeri yang ramai, menikmati hidup yang bahagia, penyiaran agama yang benar, dan tolong menolong di dalam memajukan ilmu pengetahuan. Ini semua terjadi setelah setan memutus hubungan silaturrahim antara aku dan saudara-saudaraku sehingga rusaklah hubungan persaudaraan, dan timbullah rasa dengki dan buruk sangka antara kita. Sesungguhnya Allah swt Maha Mengetahui segala sesuatu yang bagaimanapun halusnya, bersifat lemah lembut kepada hamba-hamba-Nya, dan menetapkan apa yang Dia kehendaki dengan kebijaksanaan-Nya. Sesungguhnya Dia Maha Mengetahui apa yang menjadi maslahat bagi hamba-hamba-Nya. Tiada suatu hal yang tersembunyi bagi-Nya. Mahabijaksana di dalam segala hal, membalas orang-orang yang berbuat baik dengan kebaikan, dan kesudahan yang baik diberikan kepada orang-orang yang bertakwa."
text.101:
Ayat ini adalah pernyataan dan doa yang diucapkan Yusuf a.s. sesudah Allah swt menyelamatkannya dari dalam sumur, membebaskan dari fitnah istri al-Aziz dan perempuan-perempuan lainnya, membebaskan dari penderitaan dalam penjara, dan menganugerahinya pangkat dan kedudukan sesudah bebas dari semua tuduhan yang ditujukan kepadanya. Yusuf segera berdoa memohon kepada Allah swt supaya dilipatgandakan pahalanya di akhirat kelak sebagaimana dilipatgandakan karunia yang diterimanya di dunia. Yusuf berkata, "Ya Tuhanku, Engkau telah menganugerahkan kepadaku kedudukan dan kekuasaan, mengajarkan kepadaku takbir mimpi, dan memberitahukan kepadaku hal-hal yang akan terjadi di kemudian hari dan rahasia-rahasia yang terkandung di dalam wahyu-Mu. Ya Allah! Engkaulah Pencipta langit dan bumi ini, menciptakan keduanya dengan baik dan teratur, kokoh dan rapi, Engkaulah Pelindungku di dunia dan di akhirat, melindungiku dari maksud jahat orang-orang yang memusuhiku dan orang-orang yang ingin berbuat jahat kepadaku. Ya Allah Yang Mahakuasa! Wafatkanlah aku dalam keadaan Islam, sesuai dengan wasiat leluhurku yang berbunyi:

Dan Ibrahim mewasiatkan (ucapan) itu kepada anak-anaknya, demikian pula Yakub, "Wahai anak-anakku! Sesungguhnya Allah telah memilih agama ini untukmu, maka janganlah kamu mati kecuali dalam keadaan muslim. (al-Baqarah/2: 132)

Yusuf melanjutkan doanya dengan mengatakan, "Ya Allah Ya Tuhanku! Masukkanlah aku ke dalam kelompok orang-orang yang saleh dari leluhur kami seperti Nabi Ibrahim, Ismail, dan Ishak, begitu pula dengan para nabi dan rasul sebelumnya. Engkaulah Maha Pengasih, Maha Pemurah, dan Mahakuasa atas segala sesuatu."
text.102: Pada ayat ini, Allah swt menerangkan bahwa kisah Yusuf yang telah dipaparkan di atas termasuk berita gaib. Berita gaib itu diwahyukan kepada Muhammad. Sebelumnya, ia dan umat Islam tidak mengetahuinya. Dia juga tidak mengetahui ketika saudara-saudara Yusuf bersatu dan sepakat untuk membuang Yusuf ke dalam sumur yang dalam, dan ketika mereka mengatur tipu daya dan makarnya. Muhammad saw mengetahui peristiwa yang telah dialami oleh Yusuf itu dengan perantaraan wahyu dari Allah swt. Peristiwa ini merupakan bukti yang nyata atas kebenaran kenabian dan kerasulan Muhammad saw. Bagi orang yang sadar, bukti ini menjadi alasan untuk mempercayai dan membenarkan kerasulan Muhammad saw itu.
text.103:
Pada ayat ini, diterangkan bahwa orang-orang yang telah benar-benar kafir dan terus-menerus membangkang, tidak akan beriman bagaimanapun kita mengharap dan menginginkannya, sekalipun telah diberikan alasan-alasan yang nyata dan meyakinkan. Begitu pula halnya dengan kebanyakan orang Quraisy Mekah, sekalipun telah diberikan bukti-bukti yang nyata, mereka tidak akan percaya dan tidak akan membenarkan kenabian dan kerasulan Muhammad saw. Oleh sebab itu, beriman atau tidaknya seseorang setelah menerima dakwah rasul bukan menjadi tanggung jawabnya. Firman Allah swt:

Sungguh, engkau (Muhammad) tidak dapat memberi petunjuk kepada orang yang engkau kasihi, tetapi Allah memberi petunjuk kepada orang yang Dia kehendaki, dan Dia lebih mengetahui orang-orang yang mau menerima petunjuk. (al-Qashash/28: 56)
text.104: Pada ayat ini, Allah swt mengingatkan Muhammad saw agar tidak meminta upah kepada siapa pun, sebagai imbalan dari dakwah dan anjurannya supaya mereka taat dan menyembah hanya kepada Allah swt serta meninggalkan agama berhala. Allah yang akan memberikan upah dan pahala atas usahanya itu, karena memang Al-Quran diturunkan kepadanya sebagai petunjuk melaksanakan tugasnya sebagai rasul. Al-Quran merupakan peringatan dan nasihat untuk membimbing dan memberi petunjuk kepada manusia yang akan membawa kepada kebahagiaan dunia dan akhirat.
text.105: Pada ayat ini, Allah swt menerangkan bahwa tidak sedikit tanda-tanda yang menunjukkan keesaan, kesempurnaan, dan kekuasaan-Nya, seperti matahari, bulan, bintang-bintang, gunung-gunung, lautan, tanam-tanaman, dan lain-lain, yang bisa dilihat dan disaksikan sendiri oleh manusia. Akan tetapi, mereka tidak memperhatikannya dan tidak memikir-kan hikmah-hikmah yang terkandung di dalamnya. Semua itu menunjukkan bahwa Allah swt itu Esa, tiada Tuhan melainkan Dia. Dialah yang menciptakan semua makhluk dengan sempurna dan teratur. Kalaupun ada di antara mereka yang berusaha ingin mengetahui apa yang ada di langit dan di bumi, tetapi mereka lupa kepada Penciptanya. Dengan akalnya, mereka asyik menerapkan ilmunya, mengembangkan dan memanfaatkannya, tetapi jiwa mereka kosong dari mengingat Allah dan tidak beriman kepada-Nya. Ilmu saja, meskipun ada gunanya, tetapi tidak bermanfaat di akhirat kecuali apabila dilandasi iman kepada Allah. Alangkah berbahagianya orang yang dapat menyatukan keduanya. Orang itulah yang akan memperoleh kebaikan di dunia, dan akhirat serta selamat dari azab api neraka kelak.
text.106:
Ayat ini menjelaskan keadaan orang-orang Quraisy Mekah. Di samping percaya kepada Allah yang menciptakan segala sesuatu, mereka juga menyekutukan-Nya. Kalau mereka ditanya siapa yang menciptakan semua yang ada di bumi maupun di langit, mereka akan menjawab dengan tegas bahwa yang menciptakan semuanya itu ialah Allah swt sebagai tercantum dalam Al-Quran:

Dan sungguh, jika engkau (Muhammad) tanyakan kepada mereka, "Siapakah yang menciptakan langit dan bumi?" Tentu mereka akan menjawab, "Allah." Katakanlah, "Segala puji bagi Allah," tetapi kebanyakan mereka tidak mengetahui. (Luqman/31: 25)

Pengakuan Quraisy Mekah terhadap eksistensi Allah juga diikuti dengan mempersekutukan-Nya. Mereka menyembah berhala dan menjadikan pendeta sebagai tuhan. Bahkan, ada di antara mereka yang mengatakan bahwa Allah itu mempunyai anak. Mahasuci Allah swt dari apa yang dituduhkan itu. Menyekutukan Allah itu adalah dosa yang paling besar. Ibnu Masud pernah bertanya kepada Nabi Muhammad saw tentang dosa yang paling besar. Nabi saw menjawab:

Bahwa kamu jadikan sekutu bagi Allah swt padahal Dialah yang menciptakanmu. (Riwayat al-Bukhari dan Muslim dari Ibnu Masud)
text.107:
Dalam ayat ini, Allah mempertanyakan apakah orang-orang yang mengakui Allah swt sebagai Penciptanya tetapi juga menyekutukan-Nya dengan mengadakan sembahan-sembahan selain-Nya, merasa aman dari azab yang akan menimpa mereka secara tiba-tiba. Apakah mereka merasa aman tidak akan menemui kematian secara mendadak dan tidak pernah diduga sebelumnya? Sekali-kali tidak! Sewaktu-waktu Allah swt dapat saja menimpakan azab kepada mereka, begitu juga Allah swt dapat memerintah-kan Malaikat Izrail untuk mencabut nyawanya secara mendadak tanpa diduga sebelumnya apabila Allah menghendaki. Allah swt Maha Pelaksana terhadap apa yang Dia kehendaki, sebagaimana firman-Nya:

Sungguh, Tuhanmu Maha Pelaksana terhadap apa yang Dia kehendaki. (Hud/11: 107)

Sejalan dengan ayat 107 ini, firman Allah swt:

Maka apakah orang yang membuat tipu daya yang jahat itu, merasa aman (dari bencana) dibenamkannya bumi oleh Allah bersama mereka, atau (terhadap) datangnya siksa kepada mereka dari arah yang tidak mereka sadari, atau Allah mengazab mereka pada waktu mereka dalam perjalanan; sehingga mereka tidak berdaya menolak (azab itu), atau Allah mengazab mereka dengan berangsur-angsur (sampai binasa). Maka sungguh, Tuhanmu Maha Pengasih, Maha Penyayang. (an-Nahl/16: 45-47)

Di antara hikmah disembunyikannya waktu kedatangan azab yang seolah-olah dengan tiba-tiba atau pencabutan nyawa oleh Izrail secara mendadak, ialah supaya mereka selalu siap siaga akan datangnya ajal. Dengan demikian, mereka selalu patuh dan taat dalam melaksanakan ibadah serta tidak melakukan maksiat. Mereka sadar hanya kepada Allah swt manusia menyembah dan tidak menyekutukan-Nya sedikit pun.
text.108:
Pada ayat ini, Allah swt memerintahkan kepada Muhammad saw untuk memberitahu umatnya bahwa dakwah yang dijalankannya, yang bertujuan mengajak manusia mengesakan Allah swt dan mengikhlaskan ibadah hanya kepada-Nya, adalah menjadi tugas dan kewajibannya. Rasul memiliki keyakinan bahwa usahanya ini akan berhasil karena apa yang dikemukakan dan dilaksanakannya dilandasi dengan bukti-bukti dan hujjah yang nyata. Yang demikian itu menjadi tugas dan kewajiban bagi orang-orang yang mempercayai dan mengikutinya sehingga segala macam bentuk penghambaan kepada selain Allah bisa musnah dari permukaan bumi ini. Perhatikanlah firman Allah swt yang mengajarkan cara berdakwah kepada Rasul dan umatnya:

Serulah (manusia) kepada jalan Tuhanmu dengan hikmah dan pengajaran yang baik. (an-Nahl/16: 125)

Pada potongan ayat berikutnya, Allah mengajarkan Muhammad saw untuk mensucikan-Nya dari tuduhan adanya sekutu dengan mengatakan Mahasuci Allah swt dari sangkaan bahwa Dia mempunyai sekutu dalam kekuasaan-Nya, dan ada yang wajib disembah selain Dia. Langit dan bumi serta segala isinya, bahkan semua yang ada, bertasbih menyucikan Allah dari hal yang demikian itu, firman Allah swt:

Langit yang tujuh, bumi dan semua yang ada di dalamnya bertasbih kepada Allah. Dan tidak ada sesuatu pun melainkan bertasbih dengan memuji-Nya, tetapi kamu tidak mengerti tasbih mereka. Sungguh, Dia adalah Maha Penyantun, Maha Pengampun. (al-Isra/17: 44)

Ayat 108 ini ditutup dengan satu ketegasan bahwa Nabi Muhammad saw tidak termasuk orang-orang yang musyrik.
text.109:
Pada ayat ini, Allah swt menerangkan bahwa Dia tidak mengutus rasul-rasul sebelum Muhammad saw kecuali laki-laki, bukan malaikat, dan bukan perempuan, serta menurunkan kepada mereka wahyu. Para rasul berasal dari penduduk negeri itu sendiri, supaya mereka mengikutinya. Ini merupakan jawaban terhadap tuduhan-tuduhan yang dilancarkan oleh orang-orang yang mengingkari kenabian Muhammad saw, yang menghendaki supaya rasul yang diutus itu dari jenis malaikat sebagaimana dikisahkan Allah swt di dalam firman-Nya:

Dan seandainya Allah menghendaki, tentu Dia mengutus malaikat. (al-Muminun/23: 24)

Tidakkah orang-orang musyrik Quraisy yang mendustakan kenabian Muhammad saw dan mengingkari apa yang dibawanya seperti mengesakan Allah, mengikhlaskan ibadah semata-mata hanya kepada-Nya, bepergian di muka bumi dan melihat serta menyaksikan bagaimana akibat orang-orang yang mendustakan rasul-rasul dahulu. Mereka dibinasakan dan negerinya dihancurkan, seperti yang dialami kaum Nabi Hud, kaum Nabi Saleh, dan lain-lainnya. Sebaliknya orang-orang yang percaya kepada Allah dan rasul-Nya dan takut menyekutukan Allah, tidak berbuat dosa dan maksiat, akan memperoleh kesenangan nanti di negeri akhirat yang jauh lebih baik jika dibandingkan dengan apa yang didapat orang-orang musyrik di dunia ini. Apakah mereka tidak memikirkan perbedaan imbalan dan balasan antara orang-orang yang ingkar dan orang-orang yang percaya. Kesenangan yang didapat di dunia oleh orang-orang yang ingkar itu sangat terbatas. Apabila mereka meninggal dunia berakhirlah kesenangan itu, dan di negeri akhirat kelak mereka mendapat azab yang amat pedih tak henti-hentinya. Dan kesenangan yang diperoleh orang-orang yang beriman, tidak saja di dunia tetapi sampai ke akhirat nanti, karena kesenangan yang diperolehnya itu abadi selamanya.
text.110:
Ayat ini menjelaskan sunatullah yang telah berlaku pada umat-umat terdahulu. Allah swt mengutus para rasul-Nya dengan bukti yang nyata dan diperkuat dengan mukjizat. Setelah rasul-rasul itu ditentang, didustakan, dan dimusuhi oleh kaumnya sehingga merasakan tekanan yang amat berat, timbullah perasaan seakan-akan mereka berputus asa karena tidak ada harapan lagi kaumnya akan beriman dan kemenangan yang ditunggu-tunggu belum juga datang, pada saat itulah pertolongan Allah swt datang. Sedangkan orang-orang yang mendustakan para nabi ditimpa azab dengan tiba-tiba, seperti banjir besar yang menenggelamkan kaum Nabi Nuh, angin ribut yang membinasakan kaum Â'd (kaum Nabi Hud), siksaan yang menimpa kaum samud, dan bencana yang melanda negeri kaum Nabi Luth, sebagaimana tercantum dalam firman Allah swt:

Apakah tidak sampai kepada mereka berita (tentang) orang-orang yang sebelum mereka, (yaitu) kaum Nuh, Ad, Samud, kaum Ibrahim, penduduk Madyan, dan (penduduk) negeri-negeri yang telah musnah? Telah datang kepada mereka rasul-rasul dengan membawa bukti-bukti yang nyata; Allah tidak menzalimi mereka, tetapi merekalah yang menzalimi diri mereka sendiri. (at-Taubah/9: 70)

Orang-orang Quraisy yang tidak mau insaf dan kembali ke jalan yang benar, sekalipun telah ditunjukkan bukti-bukti yang nyata, akan ditimpakan Allah azab yang pedih. Sedangkan Nabi Muhammad diberi pertolongan berupa berbagai kemenangan yang telah diperolehnya seperti Perang Badar dan pada perang-perang berikutnya. Allah swt menyelamatkan para rasul beserta kaumnya yang beriman kepada-Nya, sedang orang-orang yang ingkar kepada Allah swt dan mendustakan rasul-rasul-Nya dan agama yang dibawanya akan diazab, tidak seorang pun dari mereka yang dapat menolak dan mengelak dari azab Allah itu.
text.111:
Pada ayat ini, Allah swt menerangkan bahwa semua kisah nabi-nabi, terutama Nabi Yusuf a.s. bersama ayah dan saudara-saudaranya, adalah pelajaran bagi orang-orang yang mempunyai akal sehat. Sedang orang-orang yang lalai yang tidak memanfaatkan akal dan pikirannya untuk memahami kenyataan yang ada, maka kisah Nabi tersebut tidak akan bermanfaat baginya. Mereka tidak akan dapat mengambil pelajaran dan peringatan darinya. Seharusnya mereka memperhatikan bahwa yang mampu dan kuasa menyelamatkan Nabi Yusuf a.s. setelah dibuang ke dasar sumur, meng-angkat derajatnya sesudah ia dipenjarakan, menguasai negeri Mesir sesudah dijual dengan harga murah, meninggikan pangkatnya dari saudara-saudara-nya yang ingin membinasakannya, dan mengumpulkan mereka kembali bersama kedua orang tuanya sesudah berpisah sekian lama, tentu sanggup dan kuasa pula memuliakan Muhammad, meninggikan kalimatnya, memenangkan agama yang dibawanya, serta membantu dan menguatkannya dengan tentara, pengikut, dan pendukung setia, sekalipun di dalam menjalani semuanya itu, beliau pernah mengalami kesukaran dan kesulitan. 

Kitab suci Al-Quran yang membawa kisah-kisah tersebut, bukanlah suatu cerita yang dibuat-buat dan diada-adakan, tetapi adalah wahyu yang diturunkan Allah swt dan mukjizat yang melemahkan tokoh-tokoh sastra ulung ketika ditantang untuk menyusun yang seperti itu. Kisah-kisah itu diberitakan dari nabi yang tidak pernah mempelajari buku-buku dan tidak pernah bergaul dengan ulama-ulama cerdik pandai. Bahkan kitab Suci Al-Quran itu membenarkan isi kitab-kitab samawi yang diturunkan kepada nabi-nabi sebelumnya, seperti kitab Taurat, Injil, dan Zabur yang asli tentunya, bukan yang sudah ditambah dengan khurafat dan lain-lain hal yang tidak lagi terjaga kemurniannya. Dalam kitab suci Al-Quran diuraikan dengan jelas perintah-perintah Allah, larangan-larangan-Nya, janji-janji dan ancaman-Nya, sifat kesempurnaan yang wajib bagi-Nya dan suci dari sifat-sifat kekurangan dan hal-hal yang lain, sebagaimana firman Allah swt:

Tidak ada sesuatu pun yang Kami luputkan di dalam Kitab. (al-Anam/6: 38)

Al-Quran adalah petunjuk bagi orang-orang yang mau membacanya dengan penuh kesadaran dan yang mau meneliti dan mendalami isinya. Al-Quran juga akan membimbing mereka ke jalan yang benar dan membawa kepada kebahagiaan dunia dan akhirat. Al-Quran adalah rahmat bagi orang-orang yang beriman, yaitu mereka yang membenarkan dan mempercayai serta mengamalkan isinya, karena iman itu ialah ucapan yang dibenarkan oleh hati dan dibuktikan dengan amal perbuatan.

text.1:
The first verse of Surah Yusuf is identical in wording to the first verse of Surah Yunus, except that at the end of the first verse of Surah Yunus there is the word "al-Hakim," while in the first verse of this Surah, there is the word "al-Mubin."

Al-Hakim means full of wisdom, and al-Mubin means manifest, clear, and evident. Usually, by paying attention to the first verse of each Surah, one can already estimate the main points of the Surah's content. Surah Yunus, whose first verse ends with al-Hakim, contains matters of wisdom and philosophy, such as the issue of the oneness of Allah, His attributes, the truth of the message brought by the prophets which is strengthened by various kinds of miracles, the issue of the Day of Resurrection, the Day of Judgment, and so on. All of these are issues that must be contemplated and thought about deeply and are included in matters of wisdom and philosophy. As for Surah Yusuf, its first verse ends with al-Mubin. This indicates that it contains a very interesting story, composed with fascinating words full of eloquence and philosophy in a beautiful narrative that encourages the reader to follow it to the end, a story that deserves to be an example and role model that clearly illustrates how the life of a noble prophet from his childhood experienced various kinds of suffering until he became a respected and revered ruler in the land of Egypt.
text.2: In this verse, Allah affirms that He revealed the Quran in eloquent Arabic so that its contents and meanings could be contemplated and reflected upon. Indeed, the Quran was revealed for all of humanity, even for the jinn, but because the first to receive it were the inhabitants of Mecca, it is fitting that the word was first directed to them and subsequently applies to all of humankind. First and foremost, Allah demands the attention of the Quraysh and all Arabs so that they pay close attention to its contents because it contains various kinds of knowledge that are beneficial to them in this world and the hereafter, such as religious laws, stories of the prophets and messengers, matters related to the building of society, the principles of prosperity, ethics, philosophy, political procedures, both national and international, and so on. All of this is expressed in Arabic with a beautiful structure that is easily understood by them.
text.3:
In this verse, Allah specifically addresses His words to the Prophet Muhammad (saw) and, of course, for the attention of the Arabs and all of humanity. The mufassirun (Quranic commentators) say that Surah Yusuf is one of the surahs in the Al-Quran revealed to comfort and gladden the heart of the Prophet Muhammad (saw) when he was suffering severe pressure from the Quraysh in the form of mockery, insults, disobedience, and violence, forcing him to migrate with Abu Bakar to Medina. Indeed, this is the case because the story of Prophet Yusuf is a very interesting story, narrated in a detailed manner, each chapter containing profound wisdom and lessons of great benefit to those who pay attention to it, especially when viewed from the perspective of the beauty of the language structure and the content of the story, which was not fully known by the Prophet Muhammad (saw) himself, nor by the Quraysh and the Arabs in general.

This story, in addition to narrating the circumstances of Prophet Yaqub (a.s.) and his surviving children in the manner of Bedouin life, also narrates life in a society that was advanced and highly cultured, the life of rulers full of luxury and pleasure, and how they controlled the government and managed the country's economy. True is the word of Allah that the story of Prophet Yusuf (a.s.) that will be narrated below is the best, most interesting, and most beautifully depicted story.
text.4:
Once upon a time, the Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), peace be upon him, told his father, the Prophet Yaqub (Jacob) bin Ishaq (Isaac) bin Ibrahim (Abraham), that he had dreamed of seeing eleven stars, the sun, and the moon, all bowing down to him. Of course, *sujud* (prostration) here does not mean worship as we know it, but is merely *sujud* in a figurative sense, meaning submission and obedience. *Sujud* with the meaning of submission and obedience is also found in the Al-Quran, as in Allah's saying:

"And the herbs and the trees - both prostrate." (ar-Rahman/55: 6)

After hearing the story, the Prophet Yaqub, peace be upon him, realized that his son's dream was not an ordinary dream, but an inspiration from Allah as often experienced by the prophets. He was certain that his son would face a very important matter and, upon reaching adulthood, would become a leader to whom society would submit, including his brothers and his parents. He felt worried if this was known by his brothers, and surely they would feel jealous and envious of him and try to eliminate or destroy him, especially since they already felt that their father poured out more affection on him. The fate of his son was pictured in the imagination of the Prophet Yaqub if the dream was known by his brothers, surely they would harm him with all their efforts and tricks.
text.5:
Therefore, the Prophet Jacob, peace be upon him, said to his son, "O my son, never tell your brothers what you saw in the dream, because if they find out, they will understand the interpretation of the dream and they will be envious and jealous of you. I see that the dream is not just any dream. Your dream is an inspiration from Allah that you will later become a great and influential person, and people will submit to you, including your brothers and me and your mother. I cannot guarantee that your brothers will not take bad actions against you."

Yusuf fully understood his father's advice and always remembered and cherished it, so that later at the end of the story when he was able to meet his entire family, he still said that it was Satan who deceived his brothers, causing the relationship between him and his family to be severed, as mentioned in Allah's words:

And he (Yusuf) said, "O my father, this is the explanation of my vision of before. My Lord has made it reality. And He was certainly good to me when He took me out of prison and brought you [here] from the desert after Satan had induced [estrangement] between me and my brothers. Indeed, my Lord is Subtle in what He wills. Indeed, it is He who is the Knowing, the Wise." (Yusuf/12: 100)
text.6:
Furthermore, his father said, "Thus will your Lord choose you to be a prophet and elevate your status to become a ruler and bestow upon you various kinds of blessings and honors. He will grant you knowledge by inspiring it to you. With that knowledge, you can interpret dreams and know things that ordinary people cannot know." This was proven when Yusuf was in prison, able to interpret the dream of the King of Egypt so that he became a respected person and was appointed as the highest ruler. In addition, he was able to know what food would be brought by the prison staff before the food reached his friend's room, as mentioned in Allah's word in this surah.

He (Yusuf) said, "No food will come to you but I will inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. That is among what my Lord has taught me." (Yusuf/12: 37)

Then Jacob said again to Yusuf in this verse, "Allah will perfect His favor and bounty upon you and upon the family of Jacob, including your father, your brother, and their descendants in the future. As for His favor and bounty upon you, it is as has been explained earlier, while His favor and bounty upon your father and mother and your brothers and their descendants is their deliverance from various kinds of difficulties and dangers and obtaining honor and position in Egypt, then among the descendants of the family of Jacob, several prophets will also be appointed. All these favors and bounties have been given by Allah to your grandfather Ibrahim and Ishak. To Ibrahim, Allah promised to choose from among his family and descendants to receive prophethood and holy books."

Jacob continued, "Thus is the interpretation of the dream, and rejoice in the mercy and bounty of Allah that will be bestowed upon you, but you must be steadfast and patient in facing all its trials and full of *tawakkal* and acceptance of all that He inflicts upon you, because He is All-Wise and All-Knowing of all that He decrees."
text.7: Allah warns beforehand that in the story of Prophet Yusuf (peace be upon him) there is a good example and a lesson for those who pay attention to it, namely how great the power of Allah Almighty is, and how vast His wisdom and prudence are in arranging things in a series of events that ultimately lead to the intended goal, which is the granting of mercy and grace to those whom He loves. After that, Allah narrates how Yusuf's brothers behaved towards him.
text.8:
Yusuf's brothers said to each other, "Indeed, our father loves Yusuf and his brother Benjamin more and pours more attention on them, while we are more entitled to be loved and cared for, because we are adults who are strong and can defend him and fulfill all his needs. Our father's attitude is contrary to justice and equal rights among children. Why does father prefer two weak and helpless children over us who are strong and more capable of serving and being devoted to him?"

At first glance, the truth of Yusuf's brothers' words seems clear, as if Prophet Yaqub a.s. had made a mistake with his actions, even though he was a prophet who was always guided by Allah in all his attitudes and actions. According to narrations, Yaqub did indeed pour great attention on Yusuf, because there were premonitions and signs indicating that Yusuf had special qualities in his character and nature. These special qualities were not possessed by his other brothers. So Yaqub had great hopes for him, especially after he heard Yusuf tell his dream. If Yaqub loved Yusuf more and paid more attention to him, it was natural, because Yusuf and Benjamin were still young and needed more attention and guidance from their parents than their older brothers. It was only jealousy and envy that drove his brothers to take hostile actions against him, not because their father had deviated from the path of justice.
text.9:
In a consultation to determine the appropriate and decisive action against Yusuf (Joseph), they proposed that he be killed or thrown into a distant place, so that he would be unlikely to return or perish and die in that place of exile. Thus, their father Yaqub (Jacob) would despair and have no hope of ever seeing his most beloved son again, and over time, he would surely forget him. All this time, what has been preventing him from paying attention to them is Yusuf by his side. If Yusuf were gone or banished to a distant land, their father would surely return to paying attention to and loving them. They realized that this action was a cruel and inhumane act, a criminal act with a very great sin. However, they had strayed far from the right path and fallen into the trap of Satan, so they no longer saw the consequences of that action for their father and themselves if it were carried out.

They persuaded themselves by saying that even though they had sinned, the door to repentance was still wide open. They would repent with a sincere repentance (taubat nasuha) and would not do such a thing again, and become righteous servants of Allah. Surely Allah would accept repentance, forgive all the sins and mistakes of His servants, and thus their father would be pleased with them, and Allah would not punish them.
text.10: Apparently, there were still some among them who were unwilling to carry out that proposal and still felt affection for their brother, and in their imagination, they pictured how horrifying that act would be. He proposed that Yusuf (Joseph) not be killed if they only wanted to separate him from his father and regain their father's attention. Why should we commit murder to achieve that goal, committing a great sin that God might not forgive? He had a proposal that was not so heavily burdened with sin, which was to throw Yusuf into a well, and later he would be found by travelers and taken by them to a distant land. In this way, Yusuf would not die, and they would be free from the sin of murder, while their intention and goal would also be achieved. Finally, they accepted this proposal well, and they were determined in their hearts to carry it out.
text.11: In this verse, it is clearly reflected how great Prophet Jacob's suspicion was towards Joseph's brothers and his concern if he allowed Joseph to associate with them, especially after hearing Joseph's story about his dream. Their father's attitude was very annoying and offensive to them. They frankly said, "O our father, why do you always suspect us regarding Joseph, even though we still love and care for him, always trying to make him happy and cheerful, and it has never crossed our minds to hurt his feelings, let alone mistreat him. Why don't you let him associate and mingle with us normally, as if you are suspicious of us?"
text.12: Yusuf's brothers returned to persuade their father, stating, "Let him go with us tomorrow for recreation to the grazing area, to exercise, and to compete. We will bring delicious food and tasty fruits, which we will eat after we finish playing. We will always guard and protect him from all dangers. Entrust him to us. Insha Allah, he will be happy with us and we will be happy with him, and we will bring him home safely and without anything missing."
text.13: Jacob said to them, "O my sons! I will be anxious and sad if you take him to play sports and race and leave him alone because he is still small, and not yet able to serve you in playing? Who knows, a wolf might come and attack him while you are all engrossed in playing."
text.14: They answered, "O our father, it is not appropriate for you to be suspicious and anxious like that, and do not worry about Joseph's safety. We are all grown and mature, we are all strong men, and we have promised to protect him. What you fear is unlikely to happen, and if it does happen, what is the meaning of life for us, if we who are big and strong cannot guarantee the safety of our younger brother. Thus, we will be among the losers, people who are worthless." Finally, because of the very strong pressure from Joseph's brothers and their guarantees, with a heavy heart, Jacob was forced to give them permission to take Joseph to play with the shepherds in the desert.
text.15: In verse 10 of this surah, it has been explained that Yusuf's brothers had agreed to throw Yusuf into a well, hoping he would be found by a caravan wanting to draw water and taken to a distant land so he could no longer meet his father. This verse explains that upon arriving at a place with a well, they carried out their evil agreement and threw Yusuf into the well. Thus, they felt very happy because the specter that had haunted their souls was gone. In their opinion, it was Yusuf who had seized their father's affection, and now that he was gone, surely Jacob's affection would be poured out upon them. What about Yusuf himself, who was languishing in the dark well? Of course, he was very sad and imagined that he would die of cold and hunger and would never meet his parents and siblings again. At that very critical moment, Allah inspired him not to worry and not to be sad. Allah would protect him and release him from the danger that befell him. Later, he would receive help from a caravan, and eventually, he would attain a high position, so that he could remind his brothers of their betrayal, while they themselves would not realize that the person telling the story was Yusuf himself.
text.16: In these two verses, it is narrated that Joseph's brothers returned to Jacob at night with pale faces and with tears streaming down, saying, "O our father, what you have been worried about all this time has truly happened against our will. We went to play, and we left Joseph to guard our clothes and belongings. Apparently, without us realizing it because we were so engrossed in playing, we had become far separated from him. After we returned, we found that Joseph had been pounced upon and eaten by a wolf. We did not hear his screams and cries because we had left his place far behind. We realize that you will not believe our story, even if we tell you what actually happened because you have always been suspicious of us. But this unavoidable misfortune has happened, and we were powerless to help him."
text.17: In these two verses, it is narrated that Yusuf's brothers returned to Yaqub at night with pale faces and with tears streaming down, saying, "O our father, what you have been worried about all this time has truly happened against our will. We went to play, and we left Yusuf to guard our clothes and belongings. Apparently, without us realizing because we were so engrossed in playing, we had become far separated from him. After we returned, we found that Yusuf had been attacked and eaten by a wolf. We did not hear his screams and cries because we had left his place far behind. We realize that you will not believe our story, even though we tell you what actually happened because you have always been suspicious of us. But this unavoidable misfortune has happened, and we are powerless to help him."
text.18:
To strengthen the truth of their story, they brought Joseph's shirt, which was covered in blood, and they said to their father, "This is proof of our truth." In reality, the blood on the shirt was not Joseph's blood. Jacob looked at and examined the shirt.

He found that the shirt was only covered in blood, but it was still intact, not torn or with holes from the scratches and bites of a wolf. Surely, his brothers were the ones who had committed this injustice against him. Then he said to them, "I do not believe your fabricated story at all, and I am certain that your evil and dirty souls have influenced and driven you to commit abuse against your own brother." But what power did an old father have against his sons who were already big and strong? He could do nothing but restrain his anger and suppress the feelings of his heart that were so disappointed and sad. Now his most beloved son, on whom he always placed his hopes, was no longer beside him because of his own sons' actions. Would he seek revenge, or would he investigate himself where his son actually was, while he was powerless?

In such a situation, there was nothing better for him than to be patient and put his complete trust in Allah. This was the path chosen by Jacob, even though he remained sad and continued to weep over the loss of his beloved. He did not believe his sons' story at all. Therefore, he surrendered himself to Allah and always sought His help so that his son Joseph would be saved from all dangers.
text.19: Not long after Joseph was in the well, a caravan from Madyan came, intending to depart for Egypt. Coincidentally, their water supply had run out, so they went to the well and dropped a bucket into it to draw water. Seeing the bucket lowered into the well, Joseph's heart rejoiced, and hope arose in his heart that he would be able to escape the danger he was facing. He quickly grabbed the rope of the bucket tightly, so that the person drawing water was surprised at how heavy the well water was. But they continued to pull the rope together, and it turned out that it was not water that was being lifted, but a sweet and beautiful-looking little boy. How happy the caravan leader was to see the healthy and fresh child. He imagined in his mind that he would gain a great profit by selling him to a wealthy person in Egypt later. He quickly ordered that Joseph be hidden so that he would not be seen by other people because perhaps the people in that area would claim that the child was a child of the village residents themselves. But Allah is All-Knowing of the caravan leader's intentions, just as He knows what the purpose and intention of Joseph's brothers were in putting him in the well.
text.20:
Finally, the caravan arrived in Egypt, and there they sold Yusuf for a very cheap price compared to the high price of slaves in that land, especially since Yusuf was a handsome and healthy young man.

The commentators (mufasir) say about "a few dirhams counted" that the price was certainly less than 40 dirhams because, according to custom there, if the amount of money was 40 dirhams or more, then the money was no longer counted but weighed. They sold Yusuf for such a cheap price because they were worried that someone might find out that Yusuf was not a slave, and why he was being sold when he was a free child, the child of good people. Because of that worry, they wanted to quickly get rid of him, as long as they were given some money, no matter the amount, it was enough for them. Apparently, Allah had destined them to sell Yusuf to a very influential ruler in Egypt, namely the wealthy minister called al-Aziz, so that he would have the opportunity to ascend to power and glory.
text.21:
The minister who took Yusuf was very happy and delighted to be able to buy a child who was beautiful in appearance, fresh and healthy in body, and moreover, because there were good signs on him indicating that he would have a bright future, just like his father Jacob's premonition about him.

It is narrated that Abdullah bin Masud once said about this, "The people with the most accurate premonitions are three people: first, al-Aziz when he ordered his wife to give Yusuf a good place and position in his palace; second, the daughter of the sheikh from Madyan who asked her father to entrust the Prophet Musa a.s. with the task of tending his sheep as a hired hand; and third, Abu Bakr when he appointed Umar bin Khaththab as his successor."

Because of his joy, the minister ordered his wife, "Give him a good place in this palace. Treat him as one of the family, not as a servant or maid, because he will be of service to us and the country, or we will adopt him as a child whom we love and cherish who will become our heir later on."

Thus, Allah arranged and decreed by paving the way for Yusuf and giving him the opportunity to develop his talents and abilities so that he attained a high position in Egypt. In addition, Allah also taught him the science of interpreting dreams, and with that knowledge, he would later be able to connect with the king by interpreting the king's dream, so that he was released from prison and gained great trust, and eventually he was entrusted with the affairs of the state's treasury and wealth. Thus, Allah carries out His will, but most people do not know.
text.22:
As Joseph reached adulthood, Allah also bestowed upon him intelligence and wisdom, enabling him to offer opinions and thoughts on various problems he faced. Allah also granted him knowledge, even though he did not study. This knowledge acquired without learning is called *ilmu ladunni* because it is solely inspiration and a gift from Allah.

Thus, Allah rewarded Joseph, who never defiled himself with vile and evil deeds, always maintained the purity of his conscience, and was always patient and trusting in Allah in the face of misfortune and danger that befell him. Thus, Allah rewards every person who does good.
text.23: The wife of al-Aziz was a beautiful woman, highly respected by all the inhabitants of the palace, because in addition to being the wife of al-Aziz, she was also of high character, noble morals, free from arrogant and conceited traits, and avoided anything that would degrade her status. But after Yusuf lived in the palace as one of her family members, the wife of al-Aziz began to be attracted to him because of his morals and handsomeness. One time, after locking all the doors of the house, the wife of al-Aziz seduced Yusuf to commit adultery. Yusuf, as an honest and virtuous man, was very surprised to hear the seduction and invitation, especially since the one inviting him was the wife of his own master who had given him shelter and treated him like his own son. Furthermore, if he obeyed such an invitation, it meant that he had committed a sin that was greatly despised by Allah. Therefore, he spontaneously replied, "I seek refuge in Allah lest I fall into vile and evil deeds. Your husband is my lord, my master who has done good to me, should I repay his kindness with wickedness? This is an injustice and I will not do it because no unjust person will be successful and happy in his life."
text.24: The wife of al-Aziz did not want to stop, because she considered Yusuf as a slave who had to fulfill her desires and commands. If Yusuf refused, the wife of al-Aziz would harm him. But on Yusuf's part, he was also determined to refuse because the act violated religion, betrayed his master who had been meritorious and kind to him, and damaged his honor and the honor of his master. Yusuf and the wife of al-Aziz each had opposing determinations.
text.25: In that increasingly critical situation, one continued to press and the other continued to resist, Yusuf decided to flee from his master's wife and quickly he rushed to the door, but al-Aziz's wife grabbed his shirt from behind, tearing it. In that tug-of-war, al-Aziz appeared at the door. Immediately, al-Aziz's wife cried out, saying that Yusuf had tried to rape her by force. She asked her husband that Yusuf be given a fitting punishment. The appropriate retribution for someone who commits a crime against his family is imprisonment or a painful punishment.
text.26: This verse explains Yusuf's innocence from committing adultery. Yusuf was a young man who feared his Lord, whose faith was not shaken by the seduction of a woman. He firmly said to the minister, the woman's husband, "In this incident that occurred, it was actually the woman who seduced me and invited me to fulfill her desires, until I jumped and ran away as you found me now." In this incident of Yusuf, there were many actions the minister could have taken to seek evidence to confirm that Yusuf was innocent, because Yusuf was a slave who usually would not dare to commit adultery against his master's wife. Yusuf was found by al-Aziz jumping to get out of the house. This shows that al-Aziz saw his wife in a guilty state, wearing very fine clothes, with powder and fragrant perfumes, while there were no traces of these on Yusuf's face. As another strong piece of evidence, her husband had never seen Yusuf's bad character since Yusuf lived in his house.
text.27: With his knowledge and experience of Yusuf, al-Aziz actually believed that Yusuf was innocent. Then, this belief was further strengthened by another witness, who stated that Yusuf was innocent. This witness was the cousin of al-Aziz's wife; according to some *mufassir*, his name was Zulaikha, a clever, intelligent, and wise person. The witness said, "We heard a commotion, a struggle inside the house, until we heard the sound of fabric tearing. If Yusuf's shirt is torn in the front, then the woman is truthful and Yusuf is a liar. If his shirt is torn in the back, then Yusuf is truthful and the woman is a liar." According to some narrations, the witness to this event was a baby who was destined by Allah to be able to speak simply to be a witness. But this narration is weak. The strong opinion states that the witness in this event was the cousin of al-Aziz's wife himself.
text.28: After an investigation and exchange of ideas between the minister and his wife's family regarding this incident, Yusuf's torn shirt was examined. It turned out that the back of Yusuf's shirt was torn. It was clear in this incident that Yusuf was undeniably and undoubtedly right. Therefore, the woman's accusation against Yusuf was false. But no matter how clever a guilty person is in presenting their reasons, the guilty party will eventually be known, in accordance with the proverb: "No matter how cleverly you wrap something rotten, it will eventually stink." After the matter of this incident was clear, the minister said to his wife, "Now it is clear that you have seduced and tempted Yusuf. Know that such seduction is very dangerous. Fortunately, Yusuf is a young man with strong faith, not influenced by the temptation you did."
text.29: Furthermore, in this verse, the minister said, "O Yusuf, guard yourself, keep your mouth shut, do not tell this incident to anyone else. This incident is our secret, if it becomes known, we will be ashamed. Do not be afraid in this matter, trust that we will still protect your name, because you are truly a person of noble character and strong faith. And you, my wife, fear your Lord, ask forgiveness for your sin, because you are among those who are wrong and sinful. Your mistake is very great, namely betraying your husband, and the mistake of accusing another person who is clean and pure."
text.30: This verse explains that a secret that was kept hidden, eventually became widespread. No matter how much the minister and his entire palace family tried to cover up their household secret, their efforts were in vain. The news had become the talk of the town among the women, especially among the wives of dignitaries and kingdom leaders. They discussed how the minister's wife was seducing her servant. They didn't just say that the minister's wife had fallen in love with her servant, and no longer cared about the bad consequences that would occur, such as her husband's name being tarnished. Furthermore, they said, "Indeed, we see that the minister's wife has taken a misguided path that will lead to disgrace."
text.31:
The gossip of the women reached the ears of the minister's wife, causing her to feel anger mixed with shame. She never imagined that news about her would spread so widely, despite her efforts to conceal the secret. She sought a way to cover up the shame that had spread so far. So, she invited the prominent women to come to her house to attend a banquet. For the party, the place was arranged in the best possible way, delicious food, and various kinds of drinks were prepared. Not to be missed, fresh and sweet fruits of various types and varieties were provided on the dining table. Beautiful chairs were arranged for relaxing, enjoying the delicious food and fruits. This invitation received a warm response, especially from the women who wanted to know the event that had been the talk of the town, especially wanting to see the young man named Yusuf. The party was very lively. Laughter echoed, talk and jokes became rampant. Various foods were served continuously. So were the drinks. Finally, fruits were served. Each attendee was given a knife to peel the fruits. At that moment, the minister's wife, who was the hostess, ordered Yusuf to come out into the midst of the guests who were sitting relaxing, cutting fruits to introduce himself. So, Yusuf came out and stood in front of the guests. As soon as the women saw Yusuf's very beautiful face like a full moon, they were amazed to see him, even forgetting themselves because they were mesmerized by Yusuf's strength and handsomeness. Unconsciously, they cut their own hands and fingers with the knives in their hands, not to cut the fruits, and they did not feel the pain.

From their mouths came the words, "Perfect is Allah, he is not a human being, but a noble angel." They were so amazed and stunned to see Yusuf who was so captivating and thrilling their hearts, this is the figure they talked about every day, blaming and mocking the minister's wife.
text.32:
This verse explains that the women who were invited were amazed and fascinated by Yusuf. Seeing their reaction, the minister's wife was delighted and said, "This is Yusuf, about whom you have always gossiped and criticized my attitude towards him and the incident between me and him recently. Now you are all fascinated by looking at him. You have only glanced at him, and you have already lost yourselves. Look, you have cut your fingers because you were so fascinated by looking at Yusuf."

The wife of al-Aziz said, "I confess frankly, it was indeed I who fell in love with him, and it was I who tempted him and invited him to commit adultery. But he remained reluctant and sought refuge in his Lord. He turned away and distanced himself from me. I continued to tempt him and seduce him until he was willing to follow the desires of my lust. If he still refuses, I will tell my husband to have him imprisoned, and surely he will be humiliated. My husband would not dare to reject my proposal, and my husband will punish him according to my wishes."

She deliberately uttered those words in front of the guests at the lavish banquet, so that Yusuf himself would hear them and so that the guests could soften Yusuf's heart. It is better to obey whatever the wife of al-Aziz wants than to incur her wrath, which will ultimately lead to imprisonment, living with evil and despicable people. If Yusuf is willing to follow her wishes, of course Yusuf will be fortunate, and all the wealth and luxury of the palace can also be controlled by Yusuf. In short, everyone present at that time sided with the wife of al-Aziz, no longer blaming or mocking her. Everyone justified it, it was only fitting that the minister's wife was tempted and infatuated with Yusuf who lived in her house. So all the women joined in persuading Yusuf to obey the wishes of the minister's wife, without shame or fear.
text.33: This verse explains how firm Yusuf's heart and strong his faith were, unaffected by all the seductions and enticements, as well as all the words meant to soften Yusuf's heart that came from the mouths of those women. Yusuf was not worried by the threats and intimidation that said Yusuf would be imprisoned and punished if he did not submit to their invitation to commit adultery. Hearing all of that, Yusuf only sought refuge in Allah, bowing his head while praying that God would keep him away from the temptations of those women, saying, "My Lord, the dark and narrow prison is better for me than being in the palace, facing beautiful women who are always tempting and inviting me to fulfill their lustful desires. I fear, O Allah, if I continue to live in this palace, always facing women who tempt me, lest my spirit weaken, my faith fade, so that I fall into the valley of humiliation with them. O Allah, protect me from their temptations. There is no power and strength for me to escape from that danger except with Your help and guidance. O Allah, if it were not for Your help and guidance, I would become an ignorant person, lost on the path, and easily deceived, ultimately falling into the valley of humiliation and disobedience."
text.34: This verse explains that Yusuf was eventually put in prison. Yusuf's prayer was answered by his Lord, so that Yusuf would be protected from the temptations and deceptions of the women. So, the minister put Yusuf in prison merely to fulfill his wife's request, because his wife asked her husband not to reveal the incident and to try to calm the atmosphere of their household. Allah's purpose in granting Yusuf's prayer to enter prison was different from the purpose of the official (al-Aziz). Allah's purpose was so that Yusuf would remain pure, protected from all temptations that would defile his soul. Also, so that Yusuf would become a patient person and able to endure suffering in prison, associating with people who had long been languishing in prison with various characters, behaviors, and temperaments. Because Yusuf would be appointed by Allah as a prophet for his people. Prison was the place to mature him and the first place Allah revealed revelation to him. Therefore, Allah always guarded him, and Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of all the prayers offered and all the deeds done by His servant.
text.35: This verse explains that the minister and his wife had seen evidence that Yusuf (Joseph) was a good, honest person with noble character, and possessed strong faith and trust in his Lord. Throughout their association with Yusuf, they never saw him commit any wrongdoing. It was clear to them that Yusuf was always protected by his Lord from vile deeds. Even though he was accused, enticed, and threatened, Yusuf remained calm and always sought refuge in his Lord. This was not only clearly known by the minister and his wife, but also by the entire palace family. Even so, Yusuf was still imprisoned for an indefinite period as a fulfillment of his wife's request, so that the public would believe that Yusuf was guilty, when in fact it was his wife who was guilty. Yusuf did not feel miserable or humiliated in prison. Through his interactions in prison, Yusuf's faith grew stronger, his heart and soul became more steadfast, he learned more about the secrets of humanity, and he felt the greatness of Allah more profoundly.
text.36: This verse explains that along with Yusuf, two young men also entered the prison. According to narrations, these two young men were the former royal gardener and the former royal treasurer. Both were reprimanded for their mistakes and imprisoned. One day, Yusuf saw the two young men sitting sadly, as if in a daze. So Yusuf greeted the two young men, "Why are you in this state?" They replied, "Last night we had strange and wondrous dreams, which made us anxious and sad as you see. We do not know the interpretation of our dreams." Yusuf said to them, "Only Allah knows the interpretation of your dreams, try to tell me what your dreams were." Then one of them told his dream and said, "I dreamed that I was in a vineyard with very lush fruit and green in color. It was as if I had a glass belonging to the king in my hand. With that glass, I collected the juice after I squeezed the grapes to make a drink." After that, the other one told his dream as well, saying, "I dreamed that I was carrying a basket on my head, full of various kinds of bread and food. Suddenly, several birds flew over my head, then snatched all the bread and food in the basket and carried it far away." Both of them pleaded with Yusuf, asking Yusuf to be willing to give them the interpretation of their dreams. Their hopes were pinned on Yusuf, because Yusuf was the one they trusted the most. During their time in prison, they had come to know Yusuf as a good person, with vast knowledge, good manners, and close to his Lord.
text.37:
In this verse, it is explained that before Joseph interpreted the dreams of the two young men, he first preached about the greatness and power of Allah, about the blessings of Allah that he had received, and his stance of not submitting to false religions. Joseph said to the two young men, "Before you both receive the food sent to you, I already know what that food is and I will explain it to you now."

According to a narration, some people from the kingdom would send food mixed with poison to those who were guilty in prison, with the intention of killing them. Joseph already knew the intention of the people of the kingdom and explained it to the two young men. Joseph explained that such knowledge was a revelation from his Lord to him. "With that knowledge, I can interpret dreams, unlike soothsayers and astrologers who use the help of devils, guessing and casting spells whose guesses are not necessarily true," he said. Furthermore, Joseph explained that he did not want to be influenced by the teachings of false religions. He abandoned the beliefs of those who were not truthful, those who did not want to believe in Allah and denied the Hereafter.
text.38: In this verse, it is explained that Yusuf continued his conversation with the two young men before explaining the interpretation of their dreams. Yusuf said that he only obediently followed the religion of his forefathers, namely the religion of Prophet Ibrahim, Ishaq, and Yaqub (peace be upon them), the religion of monotheism, not a religion that associates partners with Allah. "It is not fitting for us, the prophets and messengers, to associate partners with Allah, as is the case with Pharaoh and his followers. They associate partners with Allah, such as the sun, moon, idols, and others. This belief in monotheism is a favor from Allah upon us, the prophets and messengers, as well as upon all those who have the same belief. Allah has given guidance to us and to the believers. By sending us, the prophets and messengers, we show them which is the straight path and which is the crooked path, we explain to them the true belief. However, there are still people who are not grateful to Allah," said Yusuf.
text.39: Yusuf continued his da'wah by calling out to the two young men who were his companions in prison, "O two companions of the prison, which is better: multiple gods or Allah, the One, the Prevailing?" This call was sincere from a friend who was loyal and honest to his companions. The question in this call was a confirmation, that they should stop worshiping the various gods and worship Allah, the One, the Prevailing. The various gods will not be able to help them from the torment in the Hereafter. Only Allah, the One, the Prevailing, can provide help in times of difficulty and assist in times of hardship.
text.40: Continuing from Joseph's call is that everything they worship besides Allah are false gods that have been deliberately given various names by themselves, their fathers, and their ancestors. Joseph said, "You made them, you gave them names, and you worship them as God. Yet they are weak objects that have no power whatsoever, and there is no explanation from Allah to His messengers to justify the gods you have fabricated. Indeed, the correct determination regarding divinity and worship is that which is regulated by Allah, which has been revealed to His messengers. Allah has commanded that you should worship none but Allah. To Him you pray and ask for help, to Him you prostrate yourselves. That is the straight religion. But most people do not know."
text.41: In this verse, Yusuf finally explains the interpretation of the two young men's dreams. Yusuf said, "O my two fellow inmates of the prison, as for the first dream, its interpretation is that you will soon be released from this prison and return to work as before you entered prison, namely as the king's gardener and you will give the king wine to drink. The interpretation of the second dream is that you will be crucified, then your corpse and part of your head will be eaten by birds. Such is the interpretation of the dream you asked me about, as a revelation that has been revealed to me."
text.42: This verse explains that Joseph instructed the young man who was released with the favorable interpretation to convey to the king that there were still many innocent people being punished in prison. They were punished based on false accusations, so that this would be brought to the king's attention. Also, convey to the king what he saw and heard about Joseph and the call to adhere to the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism) and other things that occurred during his time in prison. Apparently, after the young man got outside, he forgot to deliver Joseph's messages to the king, so Joseph was forced to languish in prison for several more years.
text.43: In this verse, it is explained that the king once had a very strange dream that greatly disturbed his heart. He had never had such a dream in his entire life. So, he gathered all his wise men, soothsayers, and the dignitaries of his kingdom. Then he said, "I dreamed of seeing seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean cows, and I saw seven green ears of grain and seven (others) withered. Explain to me the interpretation of my dream, if there is anyone among you who has knowledge of dream interpretation."
text.44: No one could solve the king's request. Their opinions varied; some said it was just a playful dream during sleep, while others said it was the influence of fantasies during sleep that had no meaning whatsoever. Regarding such a dream, they had no knowledge to find its interpretation.
text.45: The king was not satisfied with their answers and seemed increasingly agitated. He wanted to understand the meaning of his dream, but didn't know who to ask. After the king's cupbearer, who had once languished in prison with Yusuf, heard this news, he remembered Yusuf, who was languishing in prison and had accurately interpreted his own dream. He quickly came before the king, saying, "O my lord, in the prison there is a young man named Yusuf. He is noble, possesses deep thought, broad vision, and can also interpret dreams accurately. If my lord sends me to him, I will surely return with the interpretation of your dream, which will certainly convince you of its truth."
text.46: The king was pleased to hear the opinion of his gardener, and then sent him to meet Joseph in prison. Upon arriving at the prison and meeting Joseph, he said, "O Joseph, my noble and trustworthy brother. I have come to you to ask for the interpretation of a dream: namely, seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean cows, and seven ears of grain that are withered and dry, and also seven ears of grain that are lush. Hopefully, I will return with the interpretation of that dream from you, so that it may be known by the people, who will surely be grateful to you for all the advantages and goodness that you provide."
text.47: With all his generosity, Yusuf explained the king's dream, as if Yusuf was conveying to the king and his dignitaries, saying, "O king and all the dignitaries of the country, you will face a period of seven years full of prosperity and security. Livestock will multiply, plants will flourish, and everyone will feel happy and content. Therefore, encourage the people to cultivate during those seven years. The produce from that cultivation should be stored, the wheat stored with its stalks so that it lasts longer. A small portion should be taken out for consumption only as needed."
text.48: After that prosperous period will come a time full of misery and suffering for seven years as well. At that time, livestock will be completely destroyed, plants will not bear fruit, the air will be hot, and there will be a long dry season. Water sources will dry up and the people will suffer from food shortages. All food stores will be depleted, except for a small amount left for you to use as seed.
text.49: Then, after the period of difficulty and hardship had passed, a time of prosperous, safe, and peaceful life arrived. In that time, the earth became fertile, the rain fell very heavily, and people were seen joyfully pressing grapes in peace. They sat back, relaxed, enjoying the fruits of their gardens with their children and families. That is the interpretation of the king's dream that I convey to you to deliver to the king and his dignitaries."
text.50: This verse explains how captivated the king was by the interpretation of the dream conveyed by his messenger, so the king greatly desired to meet Joseph directly. Therefore, the king ordered him to return to Joseph in prison and said, "Go to Joseph in prison and bring him here, so that I can directly hear his words and I can gauge the extent of his knowledge and the breadth of his perspective. Hopefully, his knowledge and his perspectives will be useful to me for the safety of my nation and my country." So the messenger went to Joseph and conveyed the king's summons for him to come before the king, because the king needed his advice and would elevate him to a high rank. Joseph fulfilled the king's summons. But before Joseph came to appear before the king, Joseph asked the king's messenger to return and ask the king about the incident of the women who had cut their own fingers with knives, so that the true state of affairs would be clearly known. So that when he came before the king, he would be free from accusations because the king knew more about the deceit of those women.
text.51: After the messenger returned to the king and conveyed Joseph's request to him, the king immediately summoned the minister's wife and all the women who had cut their fingers and said to them, "What is your opinion of Joseph when you tempted him before? Because I will release Joseph from prison." They replied, "That Joseph is a pure and holy young man, Glory be to Allah, we saw nothing bad in him." The minister's wife, who was infatuated and constantly tempted Joseph while living together in her house, also said, "Joseph has been in prison for too long without any fault. I am the one who is at fault because I could not control my desires, I always tempted him." Now the truth is clear, that Joseph is not guilty and he is among the truthful.
text.52: This verse explains the wife of al-Aziz's frank confession that she was the one at fault, she was the one who seduced, but Yusuf remained reluctant and turned away, because he feared his Lord. All of this is proof of her honesty. She did not want to lie about Yusuf even though Yusuf was in prison. Also, so that her husband would know that her frankness in this way showed that she was pure, protected from vile deeds, because of the strength of Yusuf's faith. His wife did not want to be accused of treachery, because Allah SWT will not guide any act of treachery.
text.53:
In this verse, it is explained that Joseph, as a human being, acknowledges that every desire tends to and is easily commanded to do evil unless given mercy and protected by Allah. Joseph was saved from the temptation of al-Aziz's wife because of the abundance of Allah's mercy and His protection, even though as a human being, Joseph was also attracted to al-Aziz's wife as the woman was attracted to him, as explained in verse 24:

"And she certainly determined [to seduce] him, and he would have inclined to her had he not seen the proof of his Lord." (Yusuf/12: 24)

However, there is another opinion that states that verse 53 explains the confession of al-Aziz's wife with emotion and deep regret that she could not cleanse herself of her mistakes and nakedness. She also admitted that she was the one who almost betrayed her husband by seducing Joseph when her husband was not at home. To protect the good name of herself, her husband, and her family, she suggested that Joseph be imprisoned, or that he be inflicted with a painful punishment. Al-Aziz's wife had committed a double mistake, namely lying and accusing an honest and pure person and throwing him into prison.

At the end of this verse, it is explained that Allah is the Most Forgiving and the Most Merciful.
text.54: In that very moving atmosphere, the king ordered that Yusuf be brought from prison and presented before the palace. At the palace, Yusuf explained to the king all his experiences from the time he lived in al-Aziz's palace until he entered prison and finally met the king face to face. Hearing his explanation, the king became convinced that Yusuf was truly an honest and faithful man, full of responsibility, noble, knowledgeable, and steadfast and strong in his faith. Because of this conviction, the king announced before the dignitaries and leaders of the country that he had appointed Yusuf as his confidant. All state financial affairs were placed entirely under his leadership and responsibility, he was the one who had full authority to control the government, and the only person who could have direct contact with the king. According to the narration of Ibn Abbas, "When the king's messenger arrived at the prison, he said to Yusuf, "Take off the prison clothes you are wearing, put on these new clothes, and come with me to face the king." All the inmates prayed for him, and Yusuf also prayed for them in return. When he arrived at the palace, the king was very surprised because he saw that Yusuf was still young (at that time he was approximately 30 years old). "Is it this young man who has been able to interpret my dream accurately, while none of the magicians and religious leaders in my country have been able to interpret it." Then the king ordered him to sit before him and decreed, "Do not be afraid." Then a gold necklace was placed around his neck and he was given a robe of honor made of silk. A saddled horse decorated with various ornaments was also provided for him, and drums were beaten throughout Egypt as a sign and declaration that Yusuf had been appointed as the king's khalifah (right hand)." This is the narration of Ibn Abbas. Then the king decreed, "From this day on, you have a high position with us and we entrust you with all state affairs."
text.55: Then the king recounted his dream to Yusuf and asked for an explanation regarding the best course of action to overcome the seven years of drought. Yusuf requested the king to entrust all matters related to the country's economy to him so that he could manage them in the best possible way to avoid the danger of famine, even though the dry season would be very long. Furthermore, Yusuf presented his long-term plan. He said that during the long fertile season, agriculture should be increased and all the people should be ordered not to leave any land uncultivated, so that when the long dry season came, the food reserves prepared during the fertile period could be taken little by little, while the wheat stalks could be used for animal feed. The king was very pleased to hear Yusuf's opinion and became even more confident in his intelligence and wisdom. He accepted all of Yusuf's proposals. Not only agricultural affairs, but all state affairs were completely entrusted to Yusuf. Thus, Yusuf became a highly respected, honored, and loved ruler in Egypt.
text.56:
Thus, Allah arranged step by step and stage by stage to place Yusuf in a high and honorable position in Egypt and to have full power in every corner of the land. All of this is in accordance with the sunnah of Allah, which began with the dream of Prophet Yusuf seeing 11 stars, the sun, and the moon prostrating to him, which caused his father Yaqub to love him even more, causing his brothers to become even more envious of him. Then Yusuf was thrown into a well by them, then taken by a caravan that was going to Egypt, and sold to the ruler there (al-Aziz) for a very cheap price. Finally, Yusuf settled in the palace as a trusted member of the family. Then he was seduced by the wife of al-Aziz and slandered, so he was thrown into prison. In prison, Yusuf was granted by Allah the knowledge to interpret the dream of one of the inmates, and finally he interpreted the king's dream. After it was proven that Yusuf was innocent, the king's trust in him arose, that he was an honest, loyal, steadfast, and patient person in facing trials, of noble character, knowledgeable, and wise, so he was appointed as ruler.

All of these events are a series that are interconnected and closely related to one another. At first, it seemed as if Yusuf was destined to always be plagued by misfortune, but in the end, he found good fortune and happiness. He arrived in Egypt as a slave, but later became the most respected and revered person there. If he were not an honest, sincere, and kind person in all his actions, Allah would not have bestowed upon him such a great blessing. Thus, Allah bestows His mercy upon whom He wills, and indeed Allah gives manifold reward to everyone who does good.
text.57: In addition to the rewards in this world, Allah also provides in the Hereafter a better, more valuable, and more blissful reward for those who remain faithful and always fear Him, namely the Jannatun naim (Gardens of Bliss) in which there are all kinds of blessings and pleasures that have never been seen by the eye, never been heard by the ear, and never crossed the heart of man.
text.58:
In the Old Testament, Book of Genesis 42:2-25, it is mentioned that Joseph made extensive preparations and provisions to face the danger of famine during the dry season. To that end, he built large warehouses to store food produced during the fertile season. When the dry season came, it turned out that the drought did not only occur in Egypt, but also encompassed neighboring countries, especially in Palestine. News reached them that the Egyptian government had a very large supply of food, so that it could help alleviate the suffering of the people in those neighboring countries. The ruler there was willing to release some of the reserves by selling them to those who desperately needed them. Therefore, Jacob ordered his sons (Joseph's brothers) to gather merchandise and take it to Egypt to be exchanged for food.

To fulfill Jacob's request, Joseph's brothers departed, except for Benjamin because Jacob did not allow him, to buy the food they desperately needed. When they arrived there, they immediately met with Joseph, hoping to be able to buy food immediately, because this matter was entirely in Joseph's hands. When they came before him, Joseph knew that those who came were his own brothers, because their appearance and type of clothing were still etched in his memory, especially since there were ten of them. Joseph said in his heart, "There is no doubt that these are my brothers." Conversely, they did not know at all that the one they were facing was their own brother.

They no longer remembered Joseph's appearance because they had been separated for a long time, especially since the one they were facing was a prime minister with ceremonial robes and glittering decorations on his clothes. It was impossible for Joseph to hold such a high position because they had thrown him into a well. Even if he was still alive, he would certainly be a slave who was exploited by his master.
text.59:
This verse explains that Yusuf granted his brothers' request to buy the goods they brought and exchange them for food supplies. He then ordered that 10 pikul (a unit of weight) of food supplies and other necessities needed for the journey be prepared for them, because there were ten of them, each entitled to one pikul. But they told him that in their village there were 2 more people who desperately needed food supplies, namely a brother and their own father.

They pleaded that they be given 12 pikul, because the ten pikul were only enough for them, "Our father cannot come here because he is old and weak, while our brother we deliberately left behind to take care of him and please him." Hearing his brothers' explanation, Yusuf said, "If that is the case, bring your brother here as proof of the truth of all of you and we will grant your request. We have seen for ourselves that the food supplies prepared for all of you amount to 10 pikul, because we are only able to hand over one pikul for one person. Besides that, while here you have all been treated well as our guests because that is how we usually treat guests in the best possible way. Now go home and take the food supplies, then come back with merchandise to exchange for food supplies, but on the condition that you must bring your brother as proof of your truthfulness and honesty."
text.60: Furthermore, Yusuf said, "If you do not bring him, you will not receive any food supplies at all because that means you are not truthful people. We will not serve liars and deceivers, and we hate them very much. We reiterate once again, if you do not bring your brother, do not expect to be given food supplies. Do not even try to approach our land, let alone face us, because there is no place here for dishonest people."
text.61: Joseph's brothers replied, "If that is the case, we will return and strive earnestly so that our father can permit our brother to go with us to Egypt. We will tell him everything that has happened and say that we were received very well and treated as guests during our stay in Egypt."
text.62: Then Joseph ordered his officers in charge of food supplies to put all the goods they had brought back into their sacks of food without their knowledge. These goods consisted of various kinds of desert produce, such as sheepskin wool and so on.
