By returning these goods, they would fully realize how kind-hearted the ruler of Egypt was, and how great his service was to them. They had been treated as guests while in Egypt, then given food supplies, while their own merchandise was returned, as if the ten measures of food were given to them freely as a gift that was very necessary and invaluable to them. With that awareness, it was hoped that a strong determination would arise in their hearts to return to Egypt, bringing goods and bringing Benjamin as well, as Joseph had instructed.
text.63:
In this verse, it is explained that when they arrived home and met their father, Yusuf's brothers told him about all their experiences in Egypt and how well the ruler there had received them, treating them as guests. When they were about to return, they were also provided with the necessities for their journey. They were given 10 *pikul* of food, which was exchanged for the goods they had brought, because there were only ten of them.

They also told Jacob that they had told the ruler of Egypt about their elderly father and a brother who could not come because he was assigned to take care of their father. They asked to be given 12 *pikul*. The ruler replied that if it was true that they had a brother, they should bring him to Egypt. The ruler would give them more food as requested. They were warned that if Benjamin could not be brought, they should not come to Egypt again, and they would not be given food, because they would be considered liars who were not worthy of trust. Therefore, they pleaded with Jacob to allow Benjamin to go with them. Thus, they would be given food and received with a better reception because they had fulfilled their promise to bring Benjamin to Egypt. They promised to take good care of Benjamin.
text.64: Jacob was shocked to hear their request, and immediately replied, "Am I to entrust Benjamin to you as I entrusted Joseph before? Are you not satisfied with harming Joseph that now you want to harm Benjamin again? Am I to simply believe your promises and guarantees regarding Benjamin, when you made similar promises and guarantees when you wanted to take Joseph to play in the pastures in the desert? I no longer trust your words and promises. I will place my hope in Allah that He will continue to protect Benjamin, for He is the best of Protectors and the Most Merciful. To Him I entrust myself in facing all matters. He is the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, I beseech Him to always bestow His mercy upon me by protecting Benjamin and safeguarding his safety, and not to inflict trials upon me like the loss of Joseph, my beloved son. Indeed, Allah's mercy is vast and His bounty is immense."
text.65: After Joseph's brothers opened the sacks of food they brought from Egypt, they found their goods were also still inside. They said to Jacob, "O our father, the goods we brought to Egypt have been returned. This is clear evidence of how kind the ruler of Egypt is to us and how generous he is, so much so that he did not want to take our goods in exchange for the food given to us. He has helped us sincerely without expecting anything in return. Indeed, we owe him a great debt of gratitude. Therefore, we must repay his kindness and good deeds by fulfilling our promise to bring Benjamin to Egypt. If we return to Egypt with him, we will certainly get more food, at least one more load will be added because we are now eleven people. For the ruler of Egypt, one load of food will certainly not be burdensome because his warehouses are full of food."
text.66: Hearing his children's words, Jacob realized that the kindness of the ruler of Egypt must be repaid with kindness as well. There was no way to repay it except by fulfilling his children's promise to bring Benjamin, because he and his children had nothing else to offer, especially since the ruler of Egypt had refused to accept any exchange goods and returned everything. With a heavy heart, Jacob said to his children that if they had to take Benjamin to Egypt, he would not allow it except with a promise reinforced by an oath that they would truly protect Benjamin's safety and bring him back home. They were also asked to be willing to sacrifice their lives if anything endangered or threatened his life. Jacob's children agreed to swear to fulfill the conditions put forward by their father. Then they swore by mentioning the name of Allah that they would protect Benjamin's safety, defend him to the death if threatened by danger, and would bring him back home. After hearing his children's oath, Jacob's heart finally felt relieved and he said, "Allah is a witness to all your words and promises. He is the One Who watches over all your actions and deeds, and to Him I entrust the safety of my son."
text.67:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Jacob said to his sons that when they arrived at the palace of the King of Egypt, they should not enter together through one gate, but enter through different gates, so as to avoid the gaze of envious eyes or experiencing undesirable things. In addition, it was so that Benjamin could meet with Joseph separately from his other brothers.

Prophet Jacob also advised that even though they had tried to avoid various harmful possibilities, he could not prevent the decree of Allah, because the decision to determine something is only in His hands. All work must be carried out according to ability and with the conviction that the decree of Allah will surely occur, and no one can prevent it. Therefore, it is only to Him that all people should put their trust (tawakal) and surrender themselves.
text.68: When the sons of Prophet Jacob entered Joseph's palace in Egypt as he had instructed them, namely to enter from different gates, this action of theirs could not avert them in the slightest from Allah's decree. This was only a desire of Prophet Jacob that had to be fulfilled so that Joseph could meet with Benjamin privately, because the two of them would make wise plans and actions. This shows that Prophet Jacob had been given knowledge through Allah SWT's revelation, but most people do not know, including his own children.
text.69:
When Jacob's sons entered the special room, Joseph immediately recognized his younger brother, Benjamin. Joseph tried to meet with him privately, saying, "Don't be sad and worried. I am your brother, but don't tell this to the other brothers."

In a narration, it is said that when Joseph's brothers entered his place, they introduced Benjamin, saying, "This is our brother Benjamin, who was asked to come with us, now we introduce him to Your Majesty." Joseph replied, "Thank you very much, and for this kindness, we will surely provide a reward." Then Joseph prepared a meal for them, totaling eleven people. Each table was for two people, so they were all seated facing each other at five tables in five closed rooms. Only Benjamin was left alone without a partner. Joseph said to his guests, "You ten, each of you go into the rooms in pairs. Because this one, namely Benjamin, has no companion, it is better that I accompany him." After Joseph and Benjamin were alone in a room, Joseph embraced him affectionately and said, "Would you like to accept me as your brother, in place of your lost brother?" Benjamin replied, "Who would refuse to have a brother like you, who is so noble? But you were not born from my father Jacob and my mother Rachel." Unable to bear hearing those words, Joseph wept and embraced Benjamin, saying, "I am Joseph, your brother who was said to be lost." Then Joseph advised his brother not to be sad about what his brothers had done to him. Joseph also told Benjamin about his plan towards his brothers, to test them, whether their character was still the same as before or if there had been a change. The intention was so that Benjamin would not be surprised if later Joseph did things that felt strange to him.
text.70: Then, while the food supplies were being prepared, Yusuf secretly placed the king's goblet (a drinking vessel that could also be used for measuring) into Benjamin's sack. After the caravan had prepared to depart from Egypt, a messenger came pursuing the caravan, exclaiming in a loud voice, "O caravan, wait! Indeed, you are thieves."
text.71: Yusuf's brothers immediately stopped their journey and asked what item was missing from the kingdom, leading him to come after them and accuse them of being thieves.
text.72: The announcer proclaimed that the king had lost a goblet bearing the royal seal. Whoever could return the goblet would receive a reward: food supplies weighing as much as a camel could carry. The announcer further clarified that he guaranteed the reward would be given to anyone who could return it.
text.73: Yusuf's brothers said, intending to clear themselves of the accusation, "By Allah, you have certainly known that we came to Egypt, both the first and the second time, not to cause corruption in the land of Egypt by stealing or committing other crimes, and we are certain that we are not thieves."
text.74: The caller asked, "But what will be the consequence if you are lying? And it turns out the king's cup is hidden in your sacks."
text.75: They answered, "Its recompense is that whoever is found with it in his bag - then he is its penalty." The law that was in effect according to the religion brought by Prophet Jacob was that the thief would be made a slave by the one who was stolen from for one year. Thus did Allah recompense the wrongdoers.
text.76: After the caravan returned to Egypt and appeared before Yusuf, he began to inspect all of their sacks, and the last one inspected was Benjamin's sack. He deliberately did this to conceal his tactic. Then Yusuf found the missing cup in Benjamin's sack. In this way, Allah arranged Yusuf's tactic to achieve his purpose. Yusuf had no intention of punishing his brother according to the laws of the kingdom unless Allah willed it. He deliberately created this tactic merely to test the character of his brothers and not to harm Benjamin, because he had been informed about the plan beforehand. Allah raises the degrees of those He wills, whether in the form of knowledge or faith, and also shows the path of truth to achieve His purpose, just as Allah raised Yusuf's degree above his brothers. Above every knowledgeable person, there is one who is more knowledgeable. Only Allah is the All-Knowing.
text.77:
In this verse, Joseph's brothers said that if Benjamin turned out to have stolen, it was because his brother Joseph had also stolen. Their accusation that Joseph had once stolen shows that envy was still rooted in their hearts. This briefly caused feelings of annoyance within Joseph. However, with patience, Joseph was able to hide that annoyance and not show it to them.

The claim that Joseph had stolen when he was a child is actually not true. The actual event was not a case of theft, but a fabricated case so that young Joseph would remain with his aunt, and not be taken home by his father, the Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him). The case is as narrated by Mujahid (may Allah be pleased with him), who explained that Joseph, when he was a child, was cared for by his aunt who loved him very much. His aunt kept the belt of the Prophet Isaac (peace be upon him), which was passed down through generations to his eldest son. The Prophet Jacob often came to his sister to take Joseph. Because his aunt loved him so much, she kept Joseph under her care. Finally, his aunt devised a tactic by tying the heirloom belt to Joseph's waist and covering it with his clothes so it wouldn't be visible. Then, his aunt announced that the heirloom belt had been lost and stolen. Then, all family members were examined. It turned out that the belt was found being worn by Joseph. According to the Sharia of the Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him) at that time, Joseph had to be handed over to his aunt as a slave for one year. This event, among other things, was what his brothers accused him of having stolen.
text.78: This verse explains what Yusuf's brothers said to al-Aziz, that Benjamin, who was accused of being a thief, had an elderly father who could not bear to be separated from him. Benjamin was a replacement for their lost brother. Therefore, they hoped that al-Aziz would be willing to take one of them as a guarantee because Benjamin was more beloved by their father. They had also promised to safeguard Benjamin's safety during the journey. In addition, they praised al-Aziz, saying that he was a person who loved to do good. Such praise was certainly intended to have Benjamin released from detention due to the theft accusation. As guests, they felt they had received the best possible service, and it would be even more perfect if that goodness was further enhanced by fulfilling their request to allow Benjamin to return to his father, who had been afflicted with sadness due to the loss of Yusuf.
text.79: Then Joseph said to his brothers that he would be doing wrong if he released Benjamin, who had been proven to have the missing item found in his sack. He sought refuge in Allah from capturing someone except for having been proven to have stolen. If he accepted his brothers' proposal, it would mean he was acting unjustly because he would be violating the laws or regulations in force in his kingdom.
text.80: Allah informs us that when Yusuf's brothers despaired because Yusuf refused one of them to replace Benjamin, they gathered to secretly discuss what they would do next. Their eldest brother, named Yahuda, said, "Do you not know that your father, Jacob, has taken a solemn pledge from us in the name of Allah that we would truly safeguard Benjamin's safety and be able to return him to our father, unless we face a great danger that cannot be avoided? The detention of Benjamin will make our father even more sad, especially when remembering that we previously neglected Yusuf." "Therefore," Yahuda continued, "I will not leave Egypt until my father permits me to return, or until Allah gives me another decision because Allah is the All-Knowing of unseen matters and He is the best of Judges."
text.81: Then Judah ordered his other brothers to return to their father and report all that had happened to them in Egypt, in order to avoid any bad accusations. Judah said, "Return to your father and tell him that his son, Benjamin, stole the king's cup and as a result was made a slave for a year according to the prevailing law (syariat)." He also instructed his brothers to tell their father, the Prophet Jacob, that they could only testify to what they knew. They saw for themselves that the king's cup was taken from Benjamin's food sack. They could not know the unseen (perkara yang gaib) at all. If they had known that Benjamin would steal, of course they would not have made a promise to their father.
text.82: Furthermore, it is explained that Judah also suggested that his brothers tell their father to ask the people of the land where they were in Egypt to buy food supplies, because the news of the theft had already spread among them. They could also ask the caravan that came with them, and indeed they were truthful people and always reported what actually happened.
text.83: After facing his sons who gave the report as mandated by Judah, Prophet Jacob said, "Rather, your souls have enticed you to something. And why do you say that the one who steals should be made a slave for a year, when that provision only exists in our law and not in their legislation. So patience is most fitting. Perhaps Allah will bring them to me all together (Joseph, Benjamin, and Judah). Indeed, He is the Knowing, the Wise."
text.84:
Because he was unhappy to receive the report delivered by his sons, Prophet Jacob turned away from them, saying with deep sorrow, "Alas, my grief for Joseph, because I had been waiting for good news from Egypt, but in reality, I received only sad news." Due to the continuous sadness he experienced and frequent crying, Jacob's eyes turned white, so that he was like a blind man. However, he was still able to restrain his anger towards his children.

According to the world of science, when a person suffers from stress, their body reacts and raises a danger signal, triggering various biochemical reactions in the body: Adrenaline levels in the bloodstream increase; energy use and body reactions reach their peak; sugar, cholesterol, and fatty acids are channeled into the bloodstream; blood pressure increases and the pulse accelerates. When glucose is channeled to the brain, cholesterol levels rise, and all of this creates problems for the body. Perhaps this is what Prophet Yaqub (peace be upon him) experienced when he lost his beloved son, Prophet Yusuf (peace be upon him).

Severe stress can affect and even change the normal functions of the body's organs. This can have very bad consequences. As a result of stress, levels of adrenaline and cortisol in the body increase above normal limits. An increase in cortisol levels over a long period leads to disorders of the body's organs, including disorders of the pancreas. As a result, diabetes mellitus occurs, which is the destruction of the beta cells of the pancreas that produce insulin, resulting in uncontrolled blood sugar levels. In many cases, this diabetes can cause symptoms of cataracts, which is clouding of the lens of the eye, resulting in blurred vision. If the lens becomes cloudy, the light entering the eye can be scattered, resulting in blurred vision.

Eye doctors agree that inadequate or poorly controlled treatment can cause blindness in sufferers of this disease. The main symptoms of cataracts are blurred vision, progressively reduced vision, a thin membrane blocking vision, and extreme glare in bright light. In further development, vision worsens, and the pupil will appear white (there is white on the black of the eye).

Today, this "white eye" disease (cataracts) can be cured, especially with the advancement of medical technology today or because blood sugar levels can be well controlled.

Of course, it is different with Prophet Yaqub (peace be upon him), whose recovery was rapid, perhaps because of a miracle for a Prophet or perhaps as a result of his "patience." Glory be to Allah, the All-Knowing and the All-Healer.
text.85: In this verse, it is explained that upon hearing the complaints and deep sadness of their father, Jacob, the sons of Jacob, who had just returned from Egypt, said to him, beginning with an oath to Allah as a sign of their affection and love, that he should not always remember Yusuf because the Yusuf incident had long passed. If he continued to remember Yusuf, he would continue to experience deep sadness, so it was feared that he would contract a disease that would destroy him or die because of it.
text.86: In this verse, Allah recounts the response of Prophet Jacob to his sons. He said, "O my sons, do not blame and reproach me. I have never complained to you all, nor to other people, about my sorrow and distress. I only complain and convey my grievances regarding the calamity that has befallen me to Allah swt. To Him I seek protection and implore Him to remove the distress and sorrow. Let me commune with my Lord. I know from the revelation that Allah has given me that Yusuf is still alive and continues to receive sustenance. He is a chosen man of Allah. He will perfect His favor upon Yusuf and the family of Jacob. All of that you do not know, and even assume that Yusuf is dead."
text.87:
Furthermore, Jacob said to his sons that he knew, even was certain, that Joseph's dream from before was true and that they would prostrate to honor him. If they held a different opinion, Jacob reminded his sons that Allah SWT would one day reveal the truth of his opinion. To that end, he asked his sons to return to Egypt to investigate until they obtained definite news about Joseph and his brother Benjamin, and not to despair, because Allah had said:

"None despairs of Allah's mercy except those who disbelieve." (al-Hijr/15:56)

Believers will not despair because of the calamities that befall them, and their faith will not waver because of the dangers that strike. They are patient and steadfast in facing all the difficulties they experience. They willingly and sincerely accept the destiny from Allah SWT with the conviction that one day Allah will remove all those difficulties, as His word states:

"Indeed, Allah defends those who have believed." (al-Hajj/22:38)

Conclusion
text.88:
In this verse, it is explained that after Yusuf's brothers accepted their father's advice to return to Egypt, they then departed. Upon arriving in Egypt, they entered Yusuf's palace with all humility. They wanted to ascertain the truth of their father's belief that al-Aziz was Yusuf. They said to al-Aziz that they had been afflicted by the calamity of famine, causing them to become thin and weak due to a lack of food, while their family was not small. They complained about their situation to al-Aziz, with the intention of finding out about Yusuf and Benjamin. They also stated that they had come bringing merchandise that was poor and of low quality, so that perhaps no merchant would want to bid for it. They hoped that al-Aziz would help them by completing the measure of their merchandise without considering its poor quality. Any shortfall that they had to pay to him should just be given to them as charity.

Allah rewards the kindness of a person who likes to give charity, and He is the One who will replace everything that has been given in charity and spent, as His saying:

And whatever you spend of anything [in His cause] - He will compensate it; and He is the best of providers. (Saba/34: 39)
text.89:
After Jacob's sons presented their reasons for returning to Egypt, Joseph responded by reminding them of the evil they had committed against Joseph and Benjamin, his younger brother. Joseph also said that what they had done to him and his brother was a very ugly or bad deed. Perhaps due to their ignorance at that time, they did not know and feel the badness of the deed, even though it contradicted religious law (syariat agama) and violated the obligation to be kind to parents and the command to associate well with close relatives. This is a realization of what Allah had revealed to Joseph when he was thrown into the well by his brothers, as Allah swt. says:

"And We inspired to him, "You will surely inform them [someday] about this affair of theirs while they do not perceive." (Yusuf/12:15)
text.90:
After hearing Yusuf's words, a realization dawned in their hearts that the person before them was indeed Yusuf. To confirm their suspicion, they asked a question filled with astonishment, "Are you really Yusuf?" For more than two years, they had met Yusuf back and forth but did not recognize him. Conversely, Yusuf recognized them, but he kept it hidden in his heart. Yusuf answered their question by saying, "I am Yusuf whom you wronged with a considerable amount of oppression. Allah SWT has helped me and honored me to the point of giving me a high position. I was completely powerless when you planned to kill me and throw me into the bottom of a deep well. And this is my brother, Bunyamin, whom you separated from me, and then Allah SWT bestowed favor upon him as you see. Allah SWT poured out His grace upon both of us, reuniting us after being separated for so long, honoring us after being humiliated, and saving us from all trials and tribulations.

Religion has established and experience has proven that those who are pious to Allah SWT by carrying out all His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions, and are always patient in facing the trials and tribulations that befall them, as well as the deceptions of Satan and the desires of the self that always tempt them, Allah will not waste the reward of their deeds in this world, let alone in the Hereafter. In this world, they are given a way out of the difficulties they face and are given sustenance from directions they did not expect, and in the Hereafter, they are given rewards without measure. Allah SWT says:

"And whoever fears Allah - He will make for him a way out. And will provide for him from where he does not expect." (ath-thalaq/65: 2-3)

And His saying:

"Only those who are patient will be given their reward without account." (az-Zumar/39: 10)
text.91: After Joseph revealed his true identity and his brothers were convinced that al-Aziz was indeed Joseph, they honestly acknowledged the glory that Allah SWT had bestowed upon Joseph regarding his superior knowledge and the loftiness of his character. They also frankly admitted the wrong they had deliberately and premeditatedly committed against Joseph and Benjamin. A mistake that would not be forgiven by Allah SWT except with *taubat nashuha* (a sincere repentance), and could not be pardoned except with an open heart and noble character from the person concerned.
text.92:
After hearing the frank confession of guilt from his brothers, Joseph, as a prophet, a chosen man with noble character and high courtesy, clearly and unequivocally forgave all the wrongs that had been done to him and Benjamin. He prayed that Allah SWT would forgive the sins of his brothers, provided they repented with all sincerity and humility, regretted the evil deed, resolved never to repeat it, and always did good, because Allah is the Most Merciful.

The noble character and high morals possessed by Prophet Joseph (peace be upon him) were also exemplified by Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), namely when he and his army conquered the city of Mecca. After Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) performed the tawaf and then prayed two rak'ahs of sunnah prayer, he stood beside the Kaaba facing the prisoners of war and said:

"What do you expect me to do to you?" The prisoners replied, "We only expect good. You are a noble brother and the son of a noble brother." The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "I will say as my brother Joseph said, "There is no blame, reproach, or violence upon you today." Then the prisoners left (the place) as if they had been resurrected from the grave. (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah)
text.93: After Yusuf explained who he was to his brothers, he then asked them about the condition of his father. They answered that he could no longer see. Immediately, Yusuf gave his shirt to his brothers to take back to their country. Upon arriving home, the shirt should be immediately rubbed on his face, and he would surely see again. Yusuf said this based on revelation. He also knew that the cause of his father's blindness was excessive weeping. If his father knew that the shirt was his, signifying that he was still alive and safe from the persecution and trials he had experienced, his father would certainly be happy and joy would arise in his heart, and he would see again as before. This was a miracle for the Prophet Yusuf. He also asked his brothers to bring all of his family to Egypt, men, women, and children, who, according to one narration (riwayat), numbered seventy people in total.
text.94: As the caravan of Jacob's sons departed from the borders of Egypt towards the land of Syria, Jacob said to his grandchildren and relatives who were beside him at that time, "I have smelled the fragrant scent of Yusuf, like the scent I knew when he was a child. If you did not think ill of me, suspecting that I was weak in mind, my thoughts ruined because of old age, surely you would believe my words that I have truly smelled the scent of Yusuf, and he is still alive. Soon I will meet him and be happy to see him." This is a miracle for Jacob, that he could smell Yusuf's scent from a very far place, approximately eight days of camel travel at that time.
text.95: This verse explains that no one among Jacob's family justified his words; in fact, they reproached him with words that were inappropriate to say to a parent. According to them, Jacob was mistaken in feeling that he would soon meet Joseph, even though they believed Joseph had died after being devoured by a wolf. Jacob's assumption, according to them, was a sign of his error.
text.96: In this verse, Allah SWT explains that after the bearer of good news arrived at his father's place according to Joseph's instructions, Judah stepped forward, carrying Joseph's shirt and wiping it on Jacob's face. Jacob's eyes instantly regained their sight as before. Jacob said to his sons, "Did I not tell you when I sent you to Egypt to seek news of Joseph and his brother, that indeed I know through revelation from Allah SWT, not imagination or wishful thinking, that Joseph is still alive, while you did not know?" Judah's handing over of Joseph's shirt to his father as proof that Joseph was still alive reminded Jacob of Judah's handing over of Joseph's blood-stained shirt as proof that Joseph had been devoured by a wolf.
text.97: After Yusuf's brothers saw the undeniable evidence and reality, they became aware and honestly admitted their mistake. They also asked their father to seek forgiveness from Allah swt for the disobedience they had committed against their father and the injustice they had done to Yusuf. The brothers' confession of the mistakes and sins they had committed was their second confession. Before that, they had confessed their sins and mistakes before Yusuf, but at that time Yusuf directly sought forgiveness from Allah swt without a request from them.
text.98: After Jacob saw his sons' awareness and frank admission of the mistake they had made, as well as their request for their father to seek forgiveness from Allah SWT, he replied, "I will seek forgiveness for you from Allah SWT. May Allah SWT forgive you all, for He is the Oft-Forgiving, the Most Merciful. Allah will not disappoint a believer who earnestly supplicates to Him."
text.99:
In this verse, it is explained that Yusuf's brothers returned to their homeland to bring all their families to Egypt, as Yusuf had suggested. Upon arrival, they informed their parents about Yusuf's position in Egypt, where he was the all-powerful ruler. It was also conveyed that Yusuf invited all his family to settle in Egypt with him, enjoying the progress and beauty of the city. Hearing this news, they set off together for Egypt. Upon arriving in Egypt, they met Yusuf and the group that had gone to meet them on the way. Yusuf embraced his parents and said, "Enter Egypt, if Allah wills, in security." (i.e., you will not experience hardship and famine, even though the drought still grips the land). Yusuf's utterance of "Insya Allah" serves as a lesson for us Muslims that when intending to do something, it should be attributed to the will of Allah. This has been a custom for the prophets and *shiddiqin*. This is also in accordance with the meaning of Allah SWT's words:

"And never say of anything, "Indeed, I will do that tomorrow," Except [when adding], "If Allah wills." (al-Kahf/18: 23 and 24)
text.100:
This verse explains that Joseph then raised his parents and seated them on the throne as a greater honor than what he had done for his brothers. They prostrated themselves, bowing in respect to Joseph, as was customary for people to show respect to kings and dignitaries at that time. Joseph then said, "O my father! This is the interpretation of my dream of long ago when I was a child, which I conveyed to my father with the words:

Indeed, I saw [in a dream] eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating to me. (Yusuf/12: 4)

Furthermore, Joseph said, "Allah SWT has made my dream come true, not a fantasy. The eleven stars are my eleven brothers, while the sun and moon are my father and mother." It was through this family that Allah SWT preserved the descendants of Prophet Isaac, son of Prophet Abraham (AS), to develop the religion of monotheism on earth. Joseph then said to his father, "Allah SWT has been good to me. He released me from prison and appointed me as ruler. He moved my father from a simple and rough desert village to a bustling land, enjoying a happy life, spreading the true religion, and helping each other in advancing knowledge. All of this happened after Satan severed the ties of kinship between me and my brothers, thus damaging the fraternal relationship, and causing envy and suspicion between us. Indeed, Allah SWT is All-Knowing of everything, no matter how subtle, is Gentle to His servants, and determines what He wills with His wisdom. Indeed, He is All-Knowing of what is best for His servants. Nothing is hidden from Him. All-Wise in all things, rewarding those who do good with goodness, and a good end is given to those who are righteous."
text.101:
This verse is a statement and a prayer uttered by Yusuf (peace be upon him) after Allah SWT saved him from the well, freed him from the slander of al-Aziz's wife and the other women, released him from the suffering in prison, and bestowed upon him rank and position after being cleared of all accusations leveled against him. Yusuf immediately prayed, beseeching Allah SWT to multiply his reward in the Hereafter, just as He had multiplied the blessings he received in this world. Yusuf said, "My Lord, You have granted me authority and power, taught me the interpretation of dreams, and informed me of things that will happen in the future and the secrets contained within Your revelation. O Allah! You are the Creator of the heavens and the earth, creating them well and orderly, firm and neat. You are my Protector in this world and in the Hereafter, protecting me from the evil intentions of those who oppose me and those who wish to do evil to me. O Allah, the Almighty! Cause me to die in a state of Islam, in accordance with the testament of my ancestors which reads:

And Abraham instructed his sons [to do the same] and [so did] Jacob, [saying], "O my sons, indeed Allah has chosen for you this religion, so do not die except while you are Muslims." (al-Baqarah/2: 132)

Yusuf continued his prayer, saying, "O Allah, my Lord! Admit me into the company of the righteous from our ancestors, such as Prophet Ibrahim, Ismail, and Ishaq, as well as the previous prophets and messengers. You are the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, and the Most Powerful over all things."
text.102: In this verse, Allah swt explains that the story of Yusuf that has been presented above is from the news of the unseen (ghaib). This news of the unseen was revealed to Muhammad. Previously, he and the Muslim community did not know it. He also did not know when Yusuf's brothers united and agreed to throw Yusuf into a deep well, and when they arranged their deception and plot. Muhammad saw knew about the events experienced by Yusuf through revelation from Allah swt. This event is clear evidence of the truthfulness of Muhammad's prophethood and messengership. For those who are conscious, this evidence becomes a reason to believe in and affirm Muhammad's messengership.
text.103:
In this verse, it is explained that those who have truly disbelieved and continuously rebel, will not believe no matter how much we hope and desire it, even if clear and convincing reasons have been given. Similarly, with most of the Quraysh of Mecca, even if clear evidence has been given, they will not believe and will not affirm the prophethood and messengership of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. Therefore, whether or not a person believes after receiving the invitation of the Messenger is not his responsibility. Allah SWT says:

"Indeed, [O Muhammad], you do not guide whom you like, but Allah guides whom He wills. And He is most knowing of who are [rightly] guided." (al-Qashash/28: 56)
text.104: In this verse, Allah swt reminds Muhammad saw not to ask for any reward from anyone in return for his da'wah and his encouragement for them to obey and worship only Allah swt and abandon idolatry. Allah will give the reward and recompense for his efforts, because indeed the Qur'an was revealed to him as guidance in carrying out his duty as a messenger. The Qur'an is a reminder and advice to guide and give direction to mankind, which will lead to happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.105: In this verse, Allah swt explains that there are numerous signs that demonstrate His oneness, perfection, and power, such as the sun, moon, stars, mountains, seas, plants, and others, which can be seen and witnessed by humans themselves. However, they do not pay attention to them and do not contemplate the wisdoms contained within them. All of this shows that Allah swt is One, there is no God but Him. He is the One who created all creatures perfectly and orderly. Even if some of them strive to know what is in the heavens and on earth, they forget their Creator. With their intellect, they are engrossed in applying their knowledge, developing and utilizing it, but their souls are empty of remembering Allah and do not believe in Him. Knowledge alone, although useful, is not beneficial in the Hereafter unless it is based on faith in Allah. How fortunate are those who can unite both. Such people will obtain goodness in this world and the Hereafter and be saved from the torment of the fire of Hell later.
text.106:
This verse explains the condition of the Quraysh people of Mecca. Despite believing in Allah who created everything, they also associated partners with Him. If they were asked who created everything in the earth and the heavens, they would answer firmly that the one who created everything is Allah swt, as stated in the Al-Quran:

"And if you ask them, "Who created the heavens and earth?" they will surely say, "Allah." Say, "All praise is [due] to Allah"; but most of them do not know." (Luqman/31: 25)

The Quraysh of Mecca's acknowledgement of Allah's existence was also followed by associating partners with Him. They worshipped idols and made priests as gods. In fact, some of them said that Allah had a son. Exalted is Allah swt from what is attributed to Him. Associating partners with Allah is the greatest sin. Ibn Masud once asked the Prophet Muhammad saw about the greatest sin. The Prophet saw replied:

"That you make a partner for Allah swt while He is the one who created you." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Ibn Masud)
text.107:
In this verse, Allah questions whether those who acknowledge Allah SWT as their Creator but also associate partners with Him by setting up deities besides Him, feel safe from the punishment that will befall them suddenly. Do they feel safe from encountering death suddenly and unexpectedly? Certainly not! At any time, Allah SWT can inflict punishment upon them, just as Allah SWT can command the Angel of Death, Izrail, to take their lives suddenly without prior warning if Allah wills. Allah SWT is the Executor of what He wills, as stated in His word:

"Indeed, your Lord is an effective doer of what He intends." (Hud/11: 107)

In line with verse 107, Allah SWT says:

"Then do those who plot evil deeds feel secure that Allah will not cause the earth to swallow them or that the punishment will not come upon them from where they do not perceive? Or that He will not seize them during their movement, and they cannot escape? Or that He will not seize them gradually? But indeed, your Lord is Kind and Merciful." (an-Nahl/16: 45-47)

Among the wisdoms behind concealing the time of the arrival of punishment, which seems sudden, or the taking of life by Izrail unexpectedly, is so that they are always prepared for the coming of death. Thus, they are always obedient and compliant in performing worship and do not commit disobedience. They are aware that it is only to Allah SWT that humans worship and do not associate partners with Him in the slightest.
text.108:
In this verse, Allah swt commands Muhammad saw to inform his people that the *dakwah* he carries out, which aims to invite people to monotheism (to believe in the oneness of Allah swt) and to dedicate worship solely to Him, is his duty and obligation. The Messenger has the conviction that his efforts will succeed because what he presents and implements is based on clear evidence and *hujjah*. This is also the duty and obligation of those who believe in and follow him, so that all forms of servitude to other than Allah can be eradicated from the face of this earth. Pay attention to the word of Allah swt which teaches the method of *dakwah* to the Messenger and his people:

"Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction..." (an-Nahl/16: 125)

In the following part of the verse, Allah teaches Muhammad saw to sanctify Him from the accusation of having partners by saying, "Glory be to Allah swt" from the suspicion that He has partners in His power, and that there is something that must be worshipped besides Him. The heavens and the earth and all that is in them, even everything that exists, glorify Allah, sanctifying Him from such things, the word of Allah swt:

"The seven heavens and the earth and whatever is in them exalt Him. And there is not a thing except that it exalts [Allah] by His praise, but you do not understand their [way of] exalting. Indeed, He is ever Forbearing and Forgiving." (al-Isra/17: 44)

This verse 108 is closed with a firm statement that the Prophet Muhammad saw is not among the *mushrikun* (those who associate partners with Allah).
text.109:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that He did not send any messengers before Muhammad saw except men, not angels, and not women, and He sent revelation down to them. The messengers came from the inhabitants of the land itself, so that they would follow them. This is an answer to the accusations leveled by those who denied the prophethood of Muhammad saw, who wanted the messenger sent to be of the angelic type, as Allah swt relates in His word:

And if Allah had willed, He would have sent down angels. (al-Muminun/23: 24)

Do not the polytheists of Quraysh who deny the prophethood of Muhammad saw and deny what he brought, such as the oneness of Allah, dedicating worship solely to Him, travel the earth and see and witness what the consequences were for those who denied the messengers in the past? They were destroyed and their lands were ruined, as experienced by the people of Prophet Hud, the people of Prophet Saleh, and others. Conversely, those who believe in Allah and His messenger and fear associating partners with Allah, do not commit sins and transgressions, will obtain pleasure in the Hereafter, which is far better compared to what the polytheists obtain in this world. Do they not consider the difference in rewards and recompense between those who disbelieve and those who believe? The pleasure obtained in this world by those who disbelieve is very limited. When they die, that pleasure ends, and in the Hereafter they will receive a very painful and unending torment. And the pleasure obtained by those who believe is not only in this world but also until the Hereafter, because the pleasure they obtain is eternal forever.
text.110:
This verse explains the *sunnatullah* (Allah's established way) that has applied to previous communities. Allah SWT sent His messengers with clear proofs and reinforced with miracles. After the messengers were opposed, denied, and antagonized by their people, causing them to feel immense pressure, a feeling arose as if they were despairing because there was no hope that their people would believe and the victory they awaited had not yet come. At that moment, Allah SWT's help arrived. Meanwhile, those who denied the prophets were struck with sudden torment, such as the great flood that drowned the people of Prophet Noah, the violent wind that destroyed the people of 'Ad (the people of Prophet Hud), the torment that befell the people of Thamud, and the disaster that struck the land of the people of Prophet Lot, as stated in the word of Allah SWT:

"Has there not reached them the news of those before them - the people of Noah and 'Aad and Thamud and the people of Abraham and the companions of Madyan and the overturned cities? Their messengers came to them with clear proofs. And Allah would never have wronged them, but they were wronging themselves." (at-Taubah/9: 70)

The Quraysh who refused to repent and return to the right path, even though they had been shown clear proofs, would be afflicted by Allah with a painful torment. Meanwhile, Prophet Muhammad was given help in the form of various victories that he had obtained, such as the Battle of Badr and in subsequent battles. Allah SWT saved the messengers and their people who believed in Him, while those who disbelieved in Allah SWT and denied His messengers and the religion they brought would be punished, and none of them could reject or escape from that torment of Allah.
text.111:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that all the stories of the prophets, especially the story of Prophet Yusuf (peace be upon him) with his father and brothers, are lessons for those who possess sound intellect. As for those who are negligent and do not utilize their minds and thoughts to understand the existing reality, the Prophet's story will not benefit them. They will not be able to take lessons and warnings from it. They should pay attention to the fact that the One who was able and powerful to save Prophet Yusuf (peace be upon him) after he was thrown into the bottom of the well, elevate his status after he was imprisoned, grant him dominion over Egypt after he was sold for a cheap price, raise his rank above his brothers who wanted to destroy him, and reunite them with their parents after being separated for so long, is certainly able and powerful to honor Muhammad, exalt his word, make the religion he brought victorious, and help and strengthen him with loyal soldiers, followers, and supporters, even though in undergoing all of that, he experienced difficulties and hardships.

The holy book Al-Quran, which carries these stories, is not a fabricated or made-up story, but is a revelation sent down by Allah swt and a miracle that weakened the leading literary figures when challenged to compose something like it. These stories are narrated from a prophet who never studied books and never associated with intelligent scholars. Moreover, the Holy Quran confirms the contents of the heavenly books revealed to the previous prophets, such as the Torah, Gospel, and Psalms in their original form, of course, not those that have been added to with superstitions and other things that no longer maintain their purity. In the Holy Quran, Allah's commands, prohibitions, promises, and threats, the attributes of perfection that are obligatory for Him, and His freedom from attributes of deficiency and other things are clearly explained, as Allah swt says:

"We have not neglected anything in the Book." (al-Anam/6: 38)

The Quran is guidance for those who want to read it with full awareness and who want to research and delve into its contents. The Quran will also guide them to the right path and lead them to happiness in this world and the hereafter. The Quran is a mercy for those who believe, that is, those who affirm, believe in, and practice its contents, because faith is a statement affirmed by the heart and proven by deeds.
